original_text: NASA scientists discovered cyclopropenylidene in the atmosphere of Saturn's moon Titan. The simple, carbon-based molecule has never been seen in an atmosphere before. Titan has long been considered one of the most promising places to search for extraterrestrial life. Cyclopropenylidene is part of a class of molecules known to form an important part of the backbone of DNA and RNA. The presence of the molecule could mean that there could be life-giving chemistry on the moon that is not water-based.

original_text: Israel's Defense Ministry has created a laser that can intercept rockets and antitank guided missiles. It is based on a precision laser beam that can be focused on long-range targets and overcome atmospheric disturbances such as clouds and dust storms. Several high-energy electric laser beams are connected into one strong beam using an advanced algorithm. High-energy lasers are able to be used continually at a low cost. The weapon can be used as long as there is electricity. Israel's Defense Ministry has launched three programs that will use the laser system on the ground, on a maneuverable platform-mounted system, and in the air. There will be several trials of the weapon throughout the year, and if it is effective, it will be deployed to the Gaza border area.

original_text: SpaceX has posted a job for a'Resort Development Manager' to be based out of Brownsville, a town near its Boca Chica test and development site. The company is looking to hire someone to 'define all aspects of development of our Boca Chica Village Resort.' The job listing also says that the company is in search of a way to combine luxury and adventure in a seaside setting. The responsibilities of this role include identifying the market for such a resort, and providing research to support the resort's layout, design, services, amenities, and programming. The job will require the person to collaborate with architects and designers on the development of a master plan for the resort, and then oversee the construction of the resort itself. The company is also looking for someone who is able to build relationships with local government officials and stakeholders. The manager will also need to be able to communicate with media about the resort project. Within the job description, SpaceX also mentioned that the resort is not just for the company's own use, and that the resort will be made available to the public. In September, SpaceX CEO Elon Musk tweeted that he is looking at building a high-speed intercity transport system that would involve 'electric pods for long-distance travel on land.' Musk tweeted that the electric pods would travel at speeds of up to 1,220 km per hour, which is twice as fast as the speed of sound. The company is also reportedly working on a project to launch satellites into space that will deliver broadband internet to the globe. The job posting for the resort manager follows an announcement in June that SpaceX has hired British architect Jonathan Ward to design and build the company's Boca Chica launch facility. The site will be used to test rockets, including the prototype of the Starship, a 387-foot-tall (118-metre) rocket designed to reach orbit and the Moon.

original_text: Scientists at the University of Tokyo have created an artificial nose using mosquito odor receptors. The team placed the mosquito receptors on a chip and monitored the setup with a scanning ion conductance microscope (SICM). This setup allowed the researchers to test a range of odors including ammonia, ethanol, acetone, isoprene, 1-octen-3-ol, 2-phenylethanol, and 1-octen-3-one. The team was able to correctly identify all the odors and measure their intensities. The SICM-based artificial nose will find use in the medical field, allowing it to detect biomarkers in the breath of patients. This will allow doctors to detect and monitor a range of diseases including cancer, diabetes, and kidney disease. The researchers were able to detect differences in the breath of healthy individuals and those with pancreatic cancer. This could lead to the development of an artificial nose that can be used to screen patients.

original_text: An Israeli startup, Nanox, has developed a new type of X-ray machine that generates 3D images. It emits less radiation and costs a fraction of the price of conventional imaging devices. The Nanox.ARC uses a proprietary silicon chip embedded with 100 million nanocones that generate X-rays. The FDA has granted clearance for the single-source Nanox.ARC, and Nanox expects to get the same approval for its multisource Nanox.ARC and the Nanox.CLOUD. Nanox plans to deploy the multisource Nanox.ARC across the globe. The device will expand access to imaging services to the roughly two-thirds of the world's population who currently have limited or no meaningful access to imaging.

original_text: Google's Fi VPN is a service available to subscribers of its Fi network. VPNs are services that give users a private connection while using the open internet, ensuring that traffic and activity can't be intercepted or tracked. A VPN is typically used for protecting your information, whether you're on a public Wi-Fi network or not. While Google Fi is technically a VPN, it has some limitations compared to the more powerful, multi-platform VPNs out there. Fi VPN is a part of the Google Fi network, which is a hybrid of Wi-Fi and cellular connections. This is essentially a VPN because it creates a secure connection between your phone and your carrier's servers. The benefit of a VPN like this is that it's baked into the service, so you don't have to download or set up an app. Google Fi's VPN has some drawbacks, however. Most notably, it's only available on Android devices and only for people who use the Google Fi network. This means the VPN will not protect you on other devices (such as your computer or your TV), nor will it work if you're using a different mobile network (such as ATT, Verizon, or Sprint). It will also not work if you're using a Fi data-only SIM, because it requires the Fi Voice app to be installed on your device. You can find Google's VPN in the Fi app on Android. Go to Settings Network Tools VPN. Then, tap on the switch to enable it. You can turn this on and off whenever you want. As Google says, Fi's VPN is set up to "always be on" for Google's apps (such as Gmail, Maps, Google Calendar, Google Drive, and more). This is helpful for keeping your information private if you're connecting to a public Wi-Fi network or using cellular data. It also protects you from malicious Wi-Fi networks that could try to steal your data. Fi's VPN does not apply to apps you download from the Play Store. If you want to use a VPN with those apps, you'll need to download a separate VPN app, such as NordVPN or ExpressVPN. In short, Google's Fi VPN is helpful, but it's not enough to protect all of your devices or all of your data. If you're looking for a more powerful VPN, you'll need to find a paid service. What is a VPN and why do you need one?
text: Google has launched a new virtual private network (VPN) service for Android users, but it's not quite as powerful as some of the more powerful services out there.

original_text: Scientists in France have developed a method for recycling PET plastics by modifying organisms to produce an enzyme that breaks down the plastic. The broken-down plastic can then be used to create new materials. The method developed by the scientists involved a strain of the Pseudomonas putida bacterium that was genetically engineered to produce the enzyme, which was isolated from a species of fungus. The scientists then exposed the bacterium to a polyethylene terephthalate, which was broken down into its component parts. According to the researchers, the process can be used to recycle a variety of PET products, including soda bottles and clothing. The process could also be scaled up and modified to recycle other types of plastic. "We have demonstrated that our bacterial strain is very efficient at degrading PET," explained Elton Santos of the National Institute of Industrial Environment and Risks (INERIS). "We are now looking at whether this degradation can also be performed on an industrial scale. For the moment, we are working on adapting our technique to an industrial scale." PET plastics are notoriously difficult to recycle, with very few recycling programs capable of handling the material. PET plastics are also notorious for finding their way into the oceans, where they break down into microplastics that can be ingested by marine life. "We need to think about the reverse engineering of plastics," added Professor John McGeehan, a co-author of the study. "The plastics we produce at the moment are very stable so it is very difficult to recover them and turn them back into their constituent building blocks." The research has been published in the journal Science Advances.

original_text: Scientists have 3D printed cyanobacteria and graphene onto a mushroom in order to produce electricity. Shining a light on the cyanobacteria will kickstart their photosynthesis, which causes them to give off a bit of electricity called "photocurrent." The graphene is able to conduct and collect the electricity, while the mushroom keeps the cyanobacteria alive (they are hard to keep alive outside of artificial conditions). Currently, an array of these mushrooms is enough to power an LED light, but we are still a ways off from powering larger electronic devices.

The state Supreme Court on Monday rejected a request by Uber and Lyft to prevent California from classifying their drivers as employees, requiring the companies to pay them more money and benefits. The companies have been under pressure for months to reclassify their drivers, but have successfully resisted that characterization. In April 2019, the US Supreme Court declined to hear the case, upholding the California ruling. "We are pleased that the California Supreme Court denied Uber and Lyft's petition to further delay the case. "Today's decision is not only a victory for Uber and Lyft drivers, but also for all workers in California and across the country. The California Supreme Court has now confirmed that in the era of app-based employment, workers' rights do not disappear merely because a worker performs services through an app rather than in person. "These workers must be treated as employees, not independent contractors, and are therefore entitled to the wage protections afforded by the California Labor Code," Liss-Riordan added. In a statement, Lyft said: "Today, the California Supreme Court decided not to consider Lyft's appeal of a lower court decision and now the case will head back to the trial court. original_text: The Exploration Extravehicular Mobility Unit (xEMU) is a new type of spacesuit designed for protecting astronauts from the harsh environment of the lunar surface. NASA has plans to use the xEMU for its upcoming mission to the Moon. The xEMU spacesuit is a lot lighter and more flexible than the EMU, which is the type of suit currently used on the International Space Station (ISS). The xEMU is also less expensive to produce than the EMU, with a suit costing 12 million each to make. The goal of the xEMU is to make it easier for astronauts to move around when they are exploring the surface of the Moon. The suit was designed to be easier to put on and take off, as well as easier to move around in. The xEMU is a lot lighter than the EMU, weighing only 23 kilograms (50 pounds) compared to the EMU's 136 kilograms (300 pounds). The xEMU can also be used for other space missions, including trips to other planets and asteroids. The xEMU has a rear-entry design that allows astronauts to sit down while putting it on. The xEMU also has a new life-support system that reduces the number of items that need to be managed and removed. The suit has an integrated thermoregulation system that eliminates the need for a separate undergarment. The suit is made out of the same materials that are used for bulletproof vests, which means it is flexible and protective. The xEMU also has a new lithium-ion battery that weighs less than half of the battery used in the EMU. The suit is also compatible with a new suitport, which is a docking port that allows an astronaut to enter and exit the suit while inside a pressurized room. The suit has a new glove design that provides increased dexterity and comfort. NASA's plans to use the xEMU spacesuit for the Artemis Mission include having four spacesuits for the first crew to the Moon. In 2024, a crew of four astronauts will explore the surface of the Moon for seven days. The Moon landing mission is part of NASA's Artemis Mission. The four astronauts will be the first people to set foot on the Moon since 1972. The Artemis Mission is a collaboration between NASA, commercial partners, and international partners.

original_text: Large and mysterious land carvings have been discovered in India's Thar Desert. The geoglyphs may be the largest-ever graphical depictions designed by humans. They were discovered using Google Earth during an archaeological survey of the area by the Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO). The geoglyphs are more than 100 miles (160 kilometers) across and depict a bull, a boat, and a swastika. The swastika is a symbol used by Hindus, Buddhists and Jains. It has a long history and does not carry the same associations in Asia that it does in the west. The meaning of the other geoglyphs is not known. At this point it's just speculation. Some have suggested the boat might be a fishing boat, while others wonder if the bull may be a depiction of Nandi, the sacred bull from Hinduism. Google Earth images show the geoglyphs are made of dark lines, which are about 33 feet (10 meters) wide. The walls are thought to be made from a trench that was dug in the dirt. Rocks and stones were then piled along the edges of the ditches, causing the dark color. The geoglyphs are thought to be at least 1,000 years old. Radiocarbon dating will be used to determine exactly how old the geoglyphs are. The images are best viewed from space because the arid environment of the Thar Desert makes it impossible to see them from ground level. There are several other geoglyphs in the Thar Desert, although they are much smaller than the newly-discovered ones. The largest of these is of a human figure with outstretched arms and measures about 90 feet (30 m) in length. Others have been found in the Atacama Desert in Chile, the Great Basin Desert in the United States, and the Middle East. original_text: Listen Notes is a podcast search engine and database which was built without a lot of engineers and is based on easily accessible technology. Instagram was acquired by Facebook for 1 billion and it only had 13 employees, not all who were engineers. Listen Notes required a website that provided an interface for users and a search function and API for developers. It is hosted completely on AWS. The one-man business employs the service of many other companies to automate and handle tasks such as monitoring, and it is an example of how a companyapplication can be built and run using off-the-shelf tools and services found on the internet. Hiring services and on-demand contractors can save a lot of time, as well as removing the need to employ a lot of full-time employees.

original_text: Audius is a music streaming platform based on the Ethereum and Solana blockchains. It was founded in 2018 and is now the largest decentralized consumer blockchain application, with over 100,000 users and millions of plays. Audius is designed to empower content creators, artists, and listeners, while removing intermediaries from the content creation and distribution process. By using Audius, creators maintain ownership of their content while distributing their songs directly to listeners, resulting in a 85 revenue share, rather than the 70 offered by Spotify and Apple Music. Audius is an open source platform that allows anyone to create a decentralized music streaming application. The Audius network is powered by the Audius token (AUDIO). Audius operates a multi-sided marketplace that allows content creators to monetize their music, listeners to enjoy music and build playlists, and advertisers to reach Audius users. Audius has a variety of features, including: Content creators and listeners can directly interact. Audius creators are protected against fraud. Audius allows creators to collect fan data. Decentralized network and immutable records. Audius creators can pay a monthly subscription for extra features. Audius has developed a desktop app, mobile app, and web app that allows users to listen to music and build playlists. Audius Payments Audius allows creators to receive payments directly from listeners through the Audius app. Creators can set their own prices, and listeners can purchase their songs and support them on a monthly basis. Audius' apps allow users to send each other virtual gifts, or "tokens of appreciation," which can be used as tips for content creators. Audius Advertising Audius' advertising platform enables artists and listeners to make money from advertising revenue. Artists and listeners can opt in to receive advertising revenue, while advertisers can target their campaigns to Audius users. Audius Integrations Audius' open source platform enables anyone to build and deploy a blockchain-powered music streaming app. The platform can be deployed on mobile, desktop, and web. Audius operates a multi-sided marketplace that allows artists, listeners, and advertisers to interact with each other. Audius Payments allows users to transact with each other. Creators can receive payments from listeners. Audius Advertising enables listeners and creators to receive revenue from advertisers. Audius Integrations allows anyone to build and deploy a decentralized music streaming app. Audius's founder and CEO is Ranidu Lankage. Ranidu founded Audius after co-founding music streaming service 8tracks, which had over 10 million users. Prior to 8tracks, he was an engineer at Yahoo! Music. Audius's Co-founder and CTO is Roneil Rumburg. Roneil was previously a senior software engineer at EA Games. Audius has received funding from a variety of investors, including: Spark Capital - 5.5 million in Series A funding General Catalyst - 5 million in Series A funding TikTok founder Zhang Yiming - 2.5 million Tencent - 2 million Audius has a team of 15 employees, with headquarters in San Francisco.

original_text: When you want to edit something using an online tool today, you usually have to upload the file to the tool by selecting the file or dragging it into your browser. As an alternative, there are a number of services that use the clipboard to exchange data with the browser. Today, we want to take a look at one of them: Clipboard. These days, an online clipboard is something we can't imagine the web without. It's almost unimaginable to think about how we would cope without the ability to copy text from one website, only to paste it into another one a few minutes later. The clipboard is one of the most important tools we have in our arsenal to get things done. But, what if you could use the clipboard to do more than just copy and paste? What if you could use it to share photos, videos, and other files, or even to share files between two computers? Well, you actually can. There are a number of services that use the clipboard to exchange data with the browser, and today, we're going to take a look at one of them: Clipboard. As an alternative, there are a number of services that use the clipboard to exchange data with the browser. Today, we want to take a look at one of them: Clipboard. Clipboard is a service that allows you to copy and paste files between two computers. To use the service, you first need to download a small application for your computer. After you have installed the app, you can simply copy and paste files between the computer and the web. Clipboard is extremely easy to use. After you have installed the application, you simply need to copy the files and paste them to the web, or vice versa. The app is installed on your computer, and you can find it in your system tray. When you open it, you will see that the app does nothing else but display a window with the service's logo. When you copy files to the clipboard, they will appear in the list on the right. In order to use Clipboard, you first need to sign up to the service. After you have created your account, you will find a new item in the right-hand side of the app, which allows you to open the Clipboard website and log into your account. Once you have signed in, you will find yourself on a dashboard that shows you all your past and future clipboard items. If you have copied files to your clipboard, you can simply click the Paste button at the bottom of the window to paste them to the web. After you have done so, the files will appear in your browser. In the right-hand side of the window, you will find the option to download the files to your computer. In order to paste files from the web to your clipboard, you simply have to click the Download button on the website. After you have done so, the files will appear in your Clipboard app. In order to download the files, you have to click the download button on the right side of the window. Clipboard is a great service, and I was really amazed by it. I was very impressed by the speed at which the files were transferred, and it was quite surprising that the service didn't encounter any problems. Overall, Clipboard is a great service, and it is definitely a tool that you should check out if you're looking for a solution to transfer files between your computer and the web. What do you think? original_text: Research on psychedelic compounds has boomed in the last few years. Many companies are now springing up in the psychedelic sector with the aim of creating new analogs of drugs like psilocybin, LSD and DMT. Many of these drugs are currently at the preclinical stage. Much like the first half of the twentieth century, many of these drugs are being developed without proper scientific information about their effects. DMT is the main psychoactive compound in this plant and is considered illegal in most countries. However, the plant containing DMT is combined with the plant containing a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI). The MAOI helps the body metabolise DMT by blocking the enzyme monoamine oxidase (MAO) which normally degrades DMT. The Ayahuasca compound has been used by Amazonian tribes for thousands of years and is thought to have healing and spiritual properties. In recent years, scientists have been interested in Ayahuasca and have conducted many studies into it. original_text: Pfizer has developed a pill designed to stop Covid-19. It is now starting human trials on the drug, which showed no significant risks or safety concerns during its animal studies. A clinical trial of the drug in humans has already begun in the United States, with a second trial expected to start in China, Pfizer said in a statement. It said the drug, which has the potential to be a "significant addition" to the coronavirus arsenal, is a repurposed version of an antiviral drug called Chloroquine. Chloroquine, which is used to treat malaria, showed promising results in animal trials against the coronavirus, said Pfizer. It was also used to treat the SARS virus in 2003. China has been testing a number of experimental drugs to find a cure for the coronavirus, which has so far killed 1,355 people and infected over 60,000. Meanwhile, another drug company, Johnson Johnson, is planning to start a study in China of an experimental HIV medicine, lopinavir, in hopes that it could help in the fight against the coronavirus.
text: The world's biggest drugmaker, Pfizer, is planning to start a clinical trial of an experimental drug to treat the deadly coronavirus, which has killed more than 1,300 people in the Middle East.

original_text: Gravity Sketch is a program that allows people to 'paint' in 3D in Virtual Reality. Ford has recently started to explore the technology and they have a customized version designed for car design. I did a 4 day residency at the Ford VR Immersion Lab in Austin, TX to test the waters and make some work that they can use to showcase this technology. Over the course of 4 days, I made a series of paintings that take advantage of the 3D aspect of the technology. While the software is very much in development and has its quirks, it's exciting to be a part of this project and to be able to experiment with what the software has to offer. Here are a couple of samples of my work: I'm in a virtual room and can walk around and view the painting from any angle. I can then export the paintings as still images and view them from any angle in a program like Photoshop.
text: I've been working on a new software program that allows people to 'paint' in 3D in Virtual Reality for the past few months and I'm excited to be a part of it.

original_text: As COVID-19 grabs the attention of the world, the war against antibiotic-resistant bacteria wages on. The number of people dying from bacterial infections could grow from 700,000 annually last year to 10 million annually by 2050. Bacteria evolves resistance against antibiotics over time, and this process is accelerated by overuse. Felix, a biotech startup, believes that it can program viruses to target specific sites in bacteria, killing bad bacteria and halting its ability to evolve and become more resistant. The treatment is now in trials. This approach can potentially re-sensitize bacteria to traditional antibiotics.

original_text: The results of a Phase 1 trial to study the effects of microdosing LSD have been published. Researchers were testing whether microdosing psychedelics could be useful as a therapeutic approach for mental health, and the results show that the doses being used are safe. As far as we know, this is the first clinical trial of LSD microdosing. The trial was carried out by a team from the Psychiatric University Hospital in Zurich, Switzerland. It involved 20 healthy volunteers. The participants were split into two groups, with the first receiving 10 micrograms of LSD, and the second receiving a placebo. They then filled in questionnaires and had brain scans to see what the effects were. They were asked questions about their psychological health and also had their blood pressure monitored. This was a blinded trial, meaning that the participants and researchers didn't know who was receiving the drug. Overall, the results showed that the drug was safe. No serious side effects were reported by any of the volunteers. There were also no changes to their blood pressure or other physiological parameters. The researchers also found no significant differences between the two groups in terms of their psychological health. The study was a very small one and was only conducted on healthy people, so we don't know how microdosing would affect people with mental health problems. This is something that the researchers say they'd like to study further in future. This is a very interesting study, and shows that microdosing is safe in a controlled environment. It would be good to see more research on the potential benefits of this technique for mental health. The full paper is published in the journal PLoS ONE.

original_text: Cryptocurrency company Ripple has announced a major partnership with MoneyGram. MoneyGram will start using Ripple's cryptocurrency, XRP, as part of its day-to-day operations. Ripple has long argued that banks should adopt its digital tokens as a way to speed up international payments. Now it has its first major customer. MoneyGram is one of the world's largest money transfer companies. It allows customers to send and receive money in as little as ten minutes, serving millions of people each year. But the company has been struggling financially for some time.
text: One of the world's biggest money transfer companies is going to use digital tokens to help speed up its business, according to a report in the Wall Street Journal.

original_text: Apple announced updates to iOS, iPadOS, MacOS, TV OS, and WatchOS in the opening keynote for WWDC2020. Public betas will start next month. iOS 14 will introduce new capabilities for Siri, including multilingual language translation, and a new Health app. iPadOS will receive a new 15-inch layout, support for file system and external storage, and new multitasking features. A new version of macOS Catalina (10.15) will include Sidecar for wireless remote access to a Mac from an iPad. A new Mac Pro with a modular design and upgradeable parts will be available this fall. tvOS will support multiple users, and gaming support for Playstation 4 and Xbox One controllers. Apple TV will launch new series this fall. The Apple Watch Series 5 will be available in ceramic and titanium. The Series 3 is also available starting at 199. The iPhone SE2 is rumored to launch next month. Apple announced Apple News, a subscription service that offers access to over 300 magazines and newspapers. Apple Arcade is a new subscription service that offers access to a library of games for iOS, macOS, and tvOS. Apple Card is a new digital credit card that will be available in August. The Apple TV service will offer original content, including exclusive access to shows, movies, and documentaries. Apple also announced Apple TV Channels, a platform that offers access to subscription services such as HBO, Showtime, Starz, Epix, and CBS All Access.
text: Apple has announced new iPhones, a new credit card, a subscription service, and updates to all of its operating systems, as well as a new Mac Pro and Apple TV.

original_text: Daniel Wang, a professor of astronomy, has stitched together hundreds of images to create a panorama of the center of the Milky Way. The resulting map captures some of the finest details ever observed in our galaxy's core. The map depicts the center of the galaxy in the direction of the constellation Sagittarius. The center of the Milky Way is marked by a bright patch in the middle of the image that corresponds to the supermassive black hole called Sagittarius A, which is surrounded by a halo of infrared radiation. The image was assembled from data collected by the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE), a space telescope that scanned the entire sky in 2010. WISE has collected more than 2.7 million images of the sky so far, including about 15,000 images of the galactic core. The mission was recently extended through 2014. The resulting image is so large that it doesn't fit onto a single computer screen. "We had to write special software to display and manipulate the image," Wang says. Most of the features in the image are not visible to the naked eye. "The center of our galaxy is basically in the Southern Hemisphere, which you can't see from Rochester, so most people don't know what the center of the galaxy looks like," Wang says. "But it's a very dramatic and beautiful image, and people are fascinated by it." Wang will be displaying the image at an upcoming public lecture on March 13. For more on Wang's work, see "Seeing Stars" from the Winter 2012 issue of Rochester Review.

original_text: In 2017, Astrophysicists at the European Space Agency spotted an iceberg the size of Las Vegas breaking off the Pine Island Glacier in West Antarctica. The iceberg has since changed the nature of the Antarctic coastline and spawned new icebergs. Changes in the glacier were tracked over February 2019 to February 2020. A time-lapse video showing a series of 57 radar images from that period is available. The Pine Island and Thwaites glaciers contain enough water to raise worldwide sea levels by four feet. Glaciers are breaking off into the water at faster rates than ever before, occurring on a near-annual basis now compared to every four to six years in the past.

original_text: Amazon has recently come under fire as it was discovered that it previously allowed vendors the ability to bid for an Amazon's Choice badge by lowering prices and spending more money on advertising. Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) is no stranger to controversy when it comes to issues surrounding its relationship with merchants, and this week is no exception. Amazon has been accused of forcing retailers to agree to its terms, and not selling certain products at a loss, in order to be included in its "Fulfillment by Amazon" program, which provides retailers with warehouse and delivery services. In this case, however, the complaint is coming from small manufacturers, who say Amazon is "hijacking their listings" by creating its own versions of their products. "The retail giant has a well-known practice of creating its own branded versions of products sold on its platform, but the small manufacturers say Amazon is going even further by copying their unique products, even down to the product description and the photos used to advertise them," according to a report in The Verge. "Amazon is creating and selling their own products, which are now outcompeting the original manufacturer for placement in the search results," said Aaron Kellner, co-founder of Unique Innovations, a company that makes car products, including tire pressure gauges. Kellner said Amazon has been selling its own version of the company's product since 2017. He believes it's unfair for Amazon to profit from its own branded versions of products, rather than the original version. "I don't think it's fair for Amazon to make the same product and take our sales," he said. Amazon says the product listings for its own branded products are "clearly marked" so that customers can tell the difference. It also says its products are "independent of the seller" and are not affiliated with or controlled by any third-party seller. But Amazon's actions are just the latest in what has become a long list of practices that have upset vendors, many of which accuse Amazon of using their data to compete with them. Amazon has also come under fire as it was discovered that it previously allowed vendors the ability to bid for an Amazon's Choice badge by lowering prices and spending more money on advertising. Amazon discontinued the practice last month.

original_text: The US Navy has banned TikTok from government-issued mobile devices. It claims that the short-form video app is a cybersecurity threat, but declined to describe in detail what dangers the popular Chinese-owned service poses. "These applications present cybersecurity threats to the base, the network, and the Navy," the US Navy Cyber Awareness Division wrote in a July 17 advisory. "While the Navy does not prohibit the use of these apps, it is recommended that Sailors and Marines do not use them due to inherent information security risk." Also on rt.com Google removed TikTok from its Play Store for 15 mins... because of an illegal gambling app The announcement comes after the US Navy sent out a similar warning about social media app Snapchat in June. "These apps present a cybersecurity threat," it wrote. "Sailors should refrain from using them on government-provided devices." It said that TikTok and Snapchat were "mostly being used for inappropriate postings and are a cybersecurity threat due to the ability to upload and download media, which could potentially allow a malicious actor to access the device." Also on rt.com Facebook bans Chinese-owned TikTok While TikTok, owned by Chinese tech company ByteDance, has a stated policy of removing content that violates its guidelines, the US military has been critical of its moderation capabilities, and in May demanded that the company explain its policies to the US government. It is unclear why the US Navy has taken issue with TikTok while Snapchat and other social media apps are apparently safe to use on government-issued devices. original_text: Earthly is a build automation tool that executes builds in containers, making them self-contained, repeatable, portable, and parallel. It uses the same technology as Docker, but Earthly is designed to be much simpler to use. The problem we're solving When building and distributing software, developers want to be able to run their build process on any machine in the world. However, a large number of factors make this difficult. Builds can be unreliable, and are often prone to breaking. Many languages and tools have non-standard configuration that makes them difficult to set up and keep running. The solution is to encapsulate the build process inside of a container, so that everything runs on exactly the same environment. For example, if you're building an application with a frontend and backend, you could build them separately, and then put them together using a continuous integration system like Travis CI. But, most container-based solutions like Travis are complicated to use and require a lot of setup and maintenance. You end up spending more time managing the setup than you do writing the code! We believe that container-based solutions should be easy to use, so you can focus on what's important: building great software. Earthly is simple, but it's also powerful. It's fully integrated with Docker, so you can use the same commands and tools you're already familiar with. It supports both a Bash CLI and a web dashboard, and you can run builds on your own machine or on a server. You can use it for any type of project, no matter what language or tools it uses. It supports a lot of features that make builds much easier to manage. Earthly was started in 2015 by Dan Wilson, the founder of Travis CI. Dan is an active contributor to open source, and created the widely-used shell language Yeoman, as well as the build automation tools Grunt, Jekyll, and many others. Dan is also the creator of Kitematic, an open source desktop app for managing and running Docker containers on OS X. Besides Earthly, Dan's other projects include the public speaking course Speak Up, the book Beyond JavaScript, and the conference Maker. Earthly is a product of Tighten Co., a software consultancy and product agency in Chicago, Illinois.

original_text: This Twitter thread follows Facebook's company-wide end-of-year meeting. During the meeting, the speakers discuss the company's role in the major events of the year, reflecting on the role it played in the good and the bad. Facebook held an internal meeting at its Menlo Park headquarters this week. There were some grandiose statements made by the company's leaders and it was all recorded. This is part of a Twitter thread by Wired Magazine's editor-in-chief Nicholas Thompson. You can read the full thread here. 1. This week, Facebook held an internal all-hands meeting at its headquarters. There were grandiose statements made. It was recorded. I listened to the tape. Here's a sample of what the meeting discussed. 2. The meeting started with a video - lots of bright colors and pop music - which I can only assume was intended to be a counterpoint to the public mood. "When we think about the journey of our company, 2018 was undoubtedly a difficult and disappointing year." "But as I reflect on it, I feel this sense of optimism." 4. "We have faced and will continue to face significant challenges. But we're making steady progress." "We've been working on these issues for more than two years, but it takes time to get all of this right." 5. The company is "making progress" on these issues. 6. "The world has never been more connected. And more people have never been online than today." "We're helping people connect with their families and friends in ways that were never possible before." 7. "We've been able to build a global community of more than two billion people." "That's a pretty big deal." 8. "We're building tools that give people a voice. And we're helping people stay informed." "We're making it possible to bring people together for causes they care about." 9. "We're helping people find jobs and a way to move out of poverty." "We're helping small businesses succeed." 10. "We're making it possible for people to have more meaningful interactions with each other." 11. "And we're bringing people together who are far away from each other." 12. "But we're also building a place where people can come together to participate in a community." "We're the connective tissue for communities." 13. "We're building technology to make sure that people can engage in the political process and have a voice." "We want to make sure that people have a way to represent their views." "In 2018, we've worked hard to prevent our products from being used to undermine democracy." 14. We're also working to protect people's right to privacy and data. "We're holding ourselves to a higher standard." 15. "And we're starting to see real momentum." "When we think about Facebook's place in the world, we need to focus on connecting people and building communities." 16. "We need to bring the world closer together." "We have to build new experiences." "We need to build new technologies." "We need to build new ways of doing business." "We need to build new partnerships." 17. The company has already been working on some of these problems for a long time. 18. In the past year, we've seen the good that we can do. 19. Facebook is a place for people to organize and to come together. 20. We're helping people share their stories and bringing families together. 21. We're helping people find a job. 22. We're helping people find their lost friends. 23. We're helping people raise money for causes they care about. 24. We're helping people stay safe in a crisis. 25. "This year we made a lot of progress, but we still have a long way to go." 26. "If we can get this right, we can help create a more connected, kinder world." 27. "We have a responsibility to move fast, and we have a responsibility to move well." 28. "We need to keep taking the long view." 29. "The journey is 1 finished." 30. "I'm incredibly optimistic about the future." 31. "When I think about what we've built here, what we've achieved here, I'm so proud of this place

original_text: The Smart Tissue Autonomous Robot (Star) is the first robotic system to plan, adapt, and execute a surgical plan in soft tissue with minimal human intervention. It recently performed laparoscopic surgery to connect two ends of an intestine in four pigs. Connecting two ends of an intestine is a challenging procedure that requires high accuracy and consistency. Star was able to perform the procedure with significantly better results compared to humans performing the same procedure. The robot could one day be used to provide predictable and consistent patient outcomes in surgery.

original_text: Facial Recognition technology has developed quickly but the law has not yet caught up with it. Using public camera footage and images of people obtained through their employer's websites combined with Amazon's commercial face recognition service, it was possible to create a system that was able to identify individuals who had passed through the observed area. While the technology can be used for good, for example, finding missing children, the potential for abuse is high. Civil liberties advocates warn that the use of the technology by the government to target and identify citizens could have a chilling effect on free speech.

original_text: 21 feature films from Japanese animation house Studio Ghibli will be added to Netflix's library for all regions outside the US, Canada, and Japan starting next month. WarnerMedia obtained the US streaming rights for its upcoming launch of HBO Max. The movies will be subtitled in 28 languages and Netflix will be providing new dubs for up to 20 languages. The release will be staggered over the next few months. It will not include Grave of the Fireflies since Studio Ghibli doesn't hold the publishing rights for the movie.

It was written in Swift and this is made possible by the open source project 'Apple Swift'. This project compiles Swift source code and creates a Linux executable. original_text: Thousands of people protested in Belarus on the weekend over the results of the presidential election. Long-time president Alexander Lukashenko won 80 percent of the vote, extending his 26-year long rule. But opposition leader Tatyana Korotkevich, who came in second, alleges election fraud, and the European Union and the United States say the vote wasn't fair. Lukashenko, who has been ruling Belarus since 1994, had kept a tight grip on the country's media for decades. But some independent media outlets have started to emerge recently, and their content is now reaching Belarusians.
text: In our series of letters from African journalists, filmmaker and columnist Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma looks at the changing face of the media in Belarus, a former Soviet republic.

original_text: btrace is an Android trace tool based on Systrace. It supports custom and native events, and it can be set to only capture trace events of the main thread. btrace also has a feature to export traces into a format that can be used by an upcoming analysis tool for systrace traces. Check out the full documentation for btrace on the Systrace wiki. To start btrace, launch it from the command line using the btrace command. At this point, btrace will run, and start collecting traces. If you need to, you can stop btrace, and then resume it, to continue capturing traces. If you want to see the traces that btrace is collecting, you will need to start btraced (the daemon for btrace) in a separate terminal. Sometimes, systrace may be logging too many events, and the terminal cannot keep up. To make sure you do not miss events, you can use the btrace-tail command to view events as they are being logged. The events.txt file that is output can be used to feed into an analysis tool that is in development. For more information, see the analysis tool documentation.
text: btrace is an Android trace tool based on Systrace that can be used to capture trace events of the main thread in an Android application, or to export trace events into a format that is used by an upcoming analysis tool.

original_text: magniX, an Australian engineering firm, in a partnership with Harbour Air, a Canadian air-ferry service, has performed the first fully-electric commercial aircraft test flight. The 15-minute flight took place in Vancouver along the Fraser River. Electric flight technology would mean significant cost savings for airlines and zero emissions. Civil aviation is one of the fastest-growing sources of carbon emissions. Electric motors require significantly less upkeep, resulting in savings in maintenance costs. Further tests are still required before Harbour Air will be able to electrify its fleet of more than 40 seaplanes. Current battery power will allow the seaplanes to fly about 160km, which is sufficient for short-haul flights.

original_text: Google is completely reimagining mobile search. It is adding a newsfeed to its mobile search results, with news cards that look a lot like the Google News App (or Facebook, Reddit, any of these apps that use the square card design on mobile). It's also using computer vision to add more visuals to search, including a new Stories feature, which creates an auto-advancing carousel of videos, showing just the relevant section of each video. Another feature called "collections" is coming this fall, it will allow you to bookmark search results into a special viewer, where Google will also surface content suggestions. Think of it like Pinterest, but for Google search.

Think of it like Pinterest, but for Google search.

original_text: Neuromorphic computing hardware is special hardware developed to model the behavior of biological neurons. A group of researchers from the US have developed a non-silicon version of the hardware that uses hydrogen and a nickel alloy. Controlling the amount of hydrogen can switch the device among four different states, which is useful for neural-network operations. The resulting hardware can train many types of systems with fewer resources than silicon hardware without losing performance. While the hardware shows significant improvements over silicon systems, it is unlikely that it will be used commercially anytime soon.

original_text: Google is partnering with Roomba to make smart homes smarter by using maps of customers homes collected by Roomba. They want to make an integration that will let you say "OK Google, I'm going to bed," and it will turn off the lights and lock the doors. Google will also use the maps to improve Google Assistant, a voice-activated virtual assistant that competes with Amazon's Alexa. Both companies have an interest in smart home devices. Roomba is iRobot's robotic vacuum cleaner, which uses sensors to move around your home on its own. This deal with iRobot could give Google an edge against Amazon, which has been the market leader so far in the burgeoning category of smart home products. The integration of Roomba and Google would allow customers to use Google Assistant to control a variety of smart home devices, like lighting and appliances.
text: Google is teaming up with iRobot, the company behind the Roomba robot vacuum cleaner, to make smart homes more intelligent. The integration of Roomba and Google would allow customers to use Google Assistant to control a variety of smart home devices, like lighting and appliances.

original_text: A study at Columbia University Irving Medical Center has found that Far-UVC light can safely kill 99.9 of seasonal coronaviruses present in airborne droplets. Conventional UV lamps can kill viruses but they aren't used in occupied public spaces as they are a potential health hazard. Far-UFC light cannot reach or damage living cells in the body, which makes it feasible and safe to use in occupied indoor public places, significantly reducing the risk of person-to-person transmission of viruses.

The file list web page has a "View Files" button that allows the recipient to download the files. When the user clicks on the "View Files" button, Safari opens up a new window and loads the file list page using the WebKit engine. This new window has the exact same URL as the original window, however the parent window is still present and visible. The original window is rendered differently by Safari. It is rendered using the iCloud Web UI rendering engine, which does not allow the user to interact with the web page. In this window, the user cannot click on buttons or interact with the page in any way. The only thing the user can do is close the window. By design, the iCloud Web UI rendering engine is isolated from the main Safari engine. This is important for security because it allows the user to have control over the actions that are performed in a web browser. It prevents any potential malicious code from interacting with the system. When the user clicks the "View Files" button, the new window opens up and it is rendered by Safari, which means that it is rendered by the WebKit engine. The iCloud Web UI rendering engine is only used for the original window. This is the main issue that the iCloud vulnerability exploits. The iCloud Web UI rendering engine is only used for the original window. Safari loads the new window as a child of the original window, so they both have the same URL. When the user closes the child window, the original window is also closed. Since the original window is rendered using the iCloud Web UI rendering engine, it is isolated from the main Safari engine. This means that it cannot perform actions like closing the window. When the user closes the child window, the original window is also closed. Since the original window is rendered using the iCloud Web UI rendering engine, it is isolated from the main Safari engine. This means that it cannot perform actions like closing the window. However, if the user clicks "View Files" on the original window, it will trigger a new window to open. This time, the new window will open up in the iCloud Web UI rendering engine. So the process is as follows: Click "View Files" on the original window, which opens a new window in the iCloud Web UI rendering engine. Click "View Files" on the new window, which opens a new window in the WebKit engine. Click "Close" on the new WebKit window, which closes both windows. This is the loophole that the iCloud vulnerability exploits. It allows an attacker to cause the original window to close by opening and closing the window multiple times. The attacker could place a malicious script in the file list page that causes the window to open and close repeatedly. In order to test this vulnerability, I created a webpage that would automatically open and close the window 10 times. In a real attack, the script would be placed on a website that the user would have to visit in order to trigger the exploit. I then opened the file list page in Safari, and I clicked on the "View Files" button. After 30 seconds, the original window closed. The iCloud Web UI rendering engine

original_text: Fuchsia is Google's latest operating system for the Google Home Hub. The OS is only available for the first-generation Home Hub devices. Fuchsia was launched quietly. It wasn't even mentioned at Google's IO conference last week. Fuchsia is a built-from-scratch operating system that uses a microkernel that was developed in-house. Its primary app-development language is Flutter. The new system isn't expected to change the UI or functionality of the Home Hub. Google may expand Fuchsia to smartphones and laptops by 2023.

original_text: Cana has unveiled a drink machine that can synthesize almost any drink. The machine uses a cartridge that contains flavor compounds that can be combined to create the flavor of a wide variety of drinks. For now, the cartridges contain only fruit flavors, and the machine only creates non-carbonated drinks, but it's easy to imagine the machine being used to create more complex drinks. (Video via gizmag) Cana is marketing the machine to bars and restaurants. When a guest orders a drink, the bartender enters the guest's name into the machine, which then creates the drink and prints a sticker to identify it. (From gizmag) The machine is also networked, so it can be used to collect information about what drinks people are ordering. This could be useful information for the restaurant, but it could also be used for social networking. The company envisions a scenario in which a person uses the machine to order a drink and then the information is broadcast to other people in the area who have opted in to the service. This could allow people to see who else is in the bar and to invite others to join them. The machine is currently in beta-testing, and Cana is planning to bring it to market in 2010. Labels: Design, Food, Future, Innovation

original_text: Masten Space Systems will develop a lunar navigation and positioning system similar to GPS as part of a contract awarded through the Air Force Research Laboratory's AFWERX program. Current spacecraft heading to the Moon have to carry equipment onboard to detect hazards and assist with navigation. As the costs of going to orbit and beyond have decreased, it makes sense to establish a shared navigation network since space is likely to get a lot busier. A shared navigation network will lower spacecraft costs, increase payload capacity, and improve landing accuracy.

original_text: Scientists from the University of Southern California were able to visualize memories forming in the brains of genetically modified zebrafish in the lab. The team expected the brains to form a memory of the environment, but what they discovered was that the neurons created a memory of the water itself, not the environment. The team modified the genetics of the fish in order to produce a protein which is triggered by water that contains a certain chemical in it. When the fish swam through water that had that chemical in it, the protein would glow in the fish's neurons, and the fish could then be observed. This study was able to help researchers understand how fish are able to remember things, but it also gives them insight into how the human brain forms memories. The scientists found that the glowing protein in the fish's neurons was not spread out evenly. Instead, it tended to be in clumps. This is a finding that was surprising to the scientists, because it was previously believed that memories were formed evenly across the neuron. While the study was only done on fish, the scientists are very excited about the potential of their findings. They believe that they may have discovered a new area of the brain that is used to form memories. In the future, scientists will be able to focus on this new area of the brain to help develop new treatments for disorders like Alzheimer's, which cause problems with memory.
text: A new study has shown that fish can form memories by swimming through water that contains a chemical that glows in the neurons that control the brain's memory.

original_text: Scientists have determined that mantis shrimp will fight longer and harder for burrows of ideal size by pitching them against each other in a competition over preferred burrows. There were no prizes, but the competition was intense! Mantis shrimp are found in rocky reefs and shallow sandy habitats around the world. They make their homes in burrows that they dig into the sand or rock. These burrows are vital for the shrimp because they are used as a shelter against predators and to keep the temperature constant. But there is only so much of the available habitat that is suitable for burrows, so there is competition for burrow space. To find out more about this competition, scientists from the University of Bristol, UK, and St Mary's College of Maryland, USA, set up a series of competitions between mantis shrimp. They did this in the lab by positioning two shrimp in front of a piece of rock with a hole in it, which could be a potential burrow. The competition was to see which shrimp would take up residence first. If neither one did, they were pitched against each other in a repeat of the experiment. The results of the experiment revealed that a lot of time was wasted as the shrimp had to first establish who was the boss and then decide which one would move into the burrow. The mantis shrimp would fight longer and harder for a burrow of the ideal size, but not for a burrow that was either too big or too small. The researchers also found that it was more likely for the smaller shrimp to take the burrow over the larger shrimp, and that the shrimp did not always try to take the burrow. Some of the shrimp were content with just hanging around outside the burrow. This was especially so when they were paired up with a shrimp of the same size. They would rather waste time and energy fighting over a burrow than hang out and fight for nothing. The researchers also found that the competition for the ideal burrow was a better predictor of aggression than size. Mantis shrimp are known to be aggressive and have been seen biting the heads off of other mantis shrimp. It is only the larger species of mantis shrimp that have the ability to bite off the head of other shrimp. This aggressive behavior is also evident when mantis shrimp are fighting over a burrow. "In the wild, this competition will be an important part of the ecology of mantis shrimp, in particular their reproductive strategy. Males will compete for burrows to attract females, and will be aggressive towards other males who try to take over their burrows. Females may use burrows as a way to escape the males, so there is an ongoing conflict over this valuable resource," concluded study co-author Dr. Steve Taylor. The study is published in the journal Animal Behaviour. The post The Winner of the Burrow Competition Is... appeared first on Newswise.
text: One of the most common shrimps in the world has found a new way to compete for space in their burrows. The results of the experiment revealed that a lot of time was wasted as the shrimp had to first establish who was the boss and then decide which one would move into the burrow.

original_text: A college student who stole 5 million in cryptocurrencies using SIM swap attacks (hacking the user's phone and using that to gain access to their email and cryptocurrency wallets) has been sentenced to a year in prison. Nicholas Truglia, 21, is known for taking at least 5 million in cryptocurrencies. In November 2018, he was sentenced to a year in prison after pleading guilty to 21 counts of felony. SIM swap attacks are a type of hacking where the hacker gains access to the user's phone number by tricking or bribing a mobile service provider. Once the hacker has control of the phone number, he can reset the account passwords for email and other online accounts, such as cryptocurrency exchanges and online banks. However, the hacker managed to get a 6-digit code sent to the victim's phone number that allows them to reset their Gmail passwords. Hacker "asks" the mobile service provider to switch the victim's phone number to a SIM card that's under the hacker's control. The hacker now receives the victim's SMS messages, including the Gmail or other password reset codes. The hacker uses the password reset codes to access the victim's email, online banking, and cryptocurrency exchange accounts.

original_text: Zoom has bought security start-up Keybase, which will allow it to implement end-to-end encryption in its meetings. Users will not be able to call into encrypted meetings via phone, and will need to join via Zoom's desktop or mobile applications. The feature will roll out in the first half of 2020, and will be free for all Zoom customers. Zoom has been one of the fastest-growing and most popular video conferencing solutions in the market for some time now, but one of the areas it has lagged behind in is security. Encrypted meetings were the biggest gap in Zoom's security portfolio. Zoom uses end-to-end encryption in its Zoom rooms, but this is different from the kind of encryption that protects the entirety of the meeting experience. A similar product to Zoom's encrypted meetings is Google Hangouts Meet, which has been offering end-to-end encryption in its meetings for some time. Microsoft Teams' meeting security has also been improving, with the vendor announcing that it would be using end-to-end encryption in its meetings. Although Zoom has been offering some level of encryption for its meetings, until now, it has not been a true end-to-end encrypted meeting. Zoom's purchase of Keybase is an interesting move as Keybase is primarily focused on chat encryption. It will be interesting to see how the company uses Keybase's technology to implement true end-to-end encryption. The post Zoom to implement end-to-end encrypted meetings in 2020 appeared first on Cloud Tech. Byrne confirmed that he had sold a "tens of millions of dollars" of his shares in the company in order to fund an "intelligence operation" against short sellers. The Wall Street Journal reported in November 2015 that Byrne had been conducting an espionage campaign against journalists who had been critical of the company. The WSJ's John Carreyrou, who had written several critical articles about Overstock, was one of the targets of the campaign. Byrne later confirmed that he had hired a private investigator to follow journalists who had written negative articles about Overstock. While I found it unsettling, I was willing to accept Mr. Byrne's assurances that these efforts were being discontinued." original_text: Optogenetics is a method of controlling neurons with light. A team of researchers from Northwestern University built an ultraminiature, wireless, battery-free, and fully implantable optogenetics device for mice that allowed them to remotely control the neurons of the mouse. The research team is led by John A. Rogers, a pioneer of flexible electronics. The device is wirelessly powered by a laser diode that can be delivered through a fiber optic cable, which is attached to an external laser. The researchers explained that the external laser can be turned on and off with a computer, which allows them to remotely control the neurons. The researchers also said that the device can potentially be applied in other types of neuroscience experiments. The device has a battery-free design, which means that it does not use any electronics at all. Instead, the device is a series of thin, flexible silicon photonic chips. The chips are encased in a small biocompatible glass package, which can be implanted in a mouse. The photonic chips convert infrared light into blue light, which is then used to activate the neurons. These photonic chips are wirelessly powered by the laser. The battery-free design is a major advantage, as there are no issues with battery discharge, which could affect the experiments. According to the research team, the device could be used to activate neurons in other parts of the brain, which could make it possible to develop a fully implantable neural interface system. The researchers added that the device could be used in other studies in which the researchers would like to remotely control the neurons of the mice, which would allow for more flexibility in conducting the experiments.
text: Researchers have developed a device that allows them to remotely control the neurons of a mouse. A team of researchers from Northwestern University built an ultraminiature, wireless, battery-free, and fully implantable optogenetics device for mice that allowed them to wirelessly control the cells of the mouse.

original_text: Django SQL Dashboard provides an authenticated interface for executing read-only SQL queries against PostgreSQL databases. It can safely run multiple SQL queries, bookmark queries to be shared, create saved dashboards and save queries for later execution. It can also display the results as a table and render charts and dashboards for it. SQL Dashboard is built upon the Django framework and the dashboard is rendered using Panel, a data visualization library for Django. The backend implementation is in Python and is a Django project. The app requires PostgreSQL and Django for its functionality. The PostgreSQL database is used to store dashboards, charts and other user data. After installation, SQL Dashboard will be available at adminsqldashboard. The following chart types are supported. SQL Dashboard is a Django application. So all it requires is a working Django application. It is recommended to use a Virtualenv to make your life a bit easier. Follow the instructions on Installing Virtualenv to install a virtual environment. The SQL Dashboard requires PostgreSQL as the backend database. You can use sudo to install PostgreSQL. When PostgreSQL is installed, it will be available on localhost:5432. You can create a superuser if you have not already done so. It is recommended to use PostgreSQL's hstore column type. It will make your life a bit easier when you want to save dashboards to the database. SQL Dashboard provides an administrative interface that allows you to create new dashboards, save queries for later use, etc. All the operations that can be performed in the admin interface are also available as endpoints that can be invoked with HTTP requests. To perform operations through HTTP requests, you need to have a Django user with the appropriate permissions. Please visit our documentation on permissions and authorization for details on how to use them. Use curl to issue HTTP requests to the following endpoints. You need to use the Django user with the required permissions. You can download the source code from the source code repository. If you encounter any issues with the project, please feel free to create issues on GitHub. If you are interested in adding new features to SQL Dashboard, please contribute your changes to the source code. Please follow the Contributing guidelines to contribute to the project.

original_text: The US military has been building a massive database with millions of images of faces, irises, fingerprints, and DNA data over the last 15 years. There are at least 7.4 million photos of human faces in the system, including about 3.8 million images from Iraq and Afghanistan. According to the New York Times, the system, called the Automated Biometric Identification System (ABIS), is used to identify people of interest to the military and law enforcement. However, it's unclear what the purpose of the collection of millions of mugshots of everyday civilians is. The Pentagon has reportedly spent at least 4.4 billion to collect and store the biometric data of people living in the Middle East and Central Asia, but so far, no one has been able to explain why the military needs this information. But critics say the biometric database of civilians from war zones could have the potential to be abused in the future. The problem, they say, is that the data will be used to identify terrorists and criminals who may be hiding in plain sight, but the scope of the database's collection of civilians is also troubling. According to the Times, the military is using a system called the Biometric Enrolment, Screening, Verification, and Evaluation System (BEST) to collect biometric data. It's unclear how the military is going about collecting the data, but the system is reportedly used to scan people's faces at checkpoints. The FBI also uses BEST to collect biometric data, and a contractor named CACI has been working with the military for several years to collect this data. In 2012, the military revealed that it had been collecting biometric data in Afghanistan, Iraq, and other areas, and it planned to share the data with the FBI. However, the details of this data-sharing agreement have not been disclosed. The FBI has been storing biometric data for several years, and the agency has collected the fingerprints of almost 73 million people since the 1980s. The agency also has 35 million photos of people's faces, and the FBI has a database of DNA profiles. The FBI database contains information on more than 70 million people. In addition to collecting fingerprints, the FBI has been rolling out facial recognition programs to track people of interest. In June, the Electronic Frontier Foundation published a report saying that the FBI database contained errors and that the data could be used to target the wrong people. A report by the Government Accountability Office (GAO) found that the FBI's biometric database contained incorrect information. The report noted that the FBI has been using face recognition technology since 2011, but the agency has not been auditing the data to make sure the information is accurate. The GAO report found that the FBI has not been testing the quality of the facial recognition data, and the agency has not been auditing the information. The report noted that there is a chance that the information in the FBI database is inaccurate. The errors could lead to the wrong people being targeted by law enforcement. But the FBI has not been testing the data to make sure that the information is correct. The agency has been using the data for over five years, but it has not been auditing the data, and it has not tested the accuracy of the data. The FBI has not audited the data in its database to make sure that the information is accurate, and it has not tested the accuracy of its facial recognition software. The agency has been using this software since 2011. The database is called the Next Generation Identification system, and the FBI is planning to expand it to include 52 million photos by 2015. The database will include information from state driver's license photos and mugshots from state and local law enforcement agencies. The FBI has not said whether the biometric data is being shared with other agencies, including the CIA, NSA, and local law enforcement agencies. In addition to collecting biometric data on civilians, the military has been using biometric technology to track down terrorists and criminals. For example, the FBI, CIA, and the military have been using a biometric system to track down criminals and terrorists in the Middle East. The biometric system was used to identify the Boston Marathon bombers. The system is called the Biometric Identification System for Access (BISA), and it's used by the FBI,

original_text: A quantum effect called superabsorption allows a collection of molecules to absorb light more efficiently than if each molecule were acting individually. Researchers have used this phenomenon to create a new type of optical device that could improve the sensitivity of solar cells, cameras, and other devices. The system, described today in Nature, consists of two microscopic silicon wires arranged so that they face each other and are spaced only nanometers apart. The researchers found that when light hit one wire, it would appear to be absorbed by the other wire. The effect could be observed even if the wires were separated by a distance five times larger than the light's wavelength. The phenomenon is the result of quantum effects that cause light to "tunnel" through the space between the wires. When the light reaches the second wire, it appears as if it was emitted there. This is similar to the way that an electron in one quantum state can tunnel into a different quantum state - an effect that is widely used in many kinds of devices, such as the tunnel diodes used in transistor radios. The effect has been observed in the lab before, but this is the first time it has been seen in a silicon-based device. The finding may enable researchers to integrate the effect into silicon-based systems, which are important in a wide range of optical applications. It's been known for some time that when you have a system in which two resonators are very close to each other, there can be a coupling effect, called vacuum Rabi splitting, which enhances the interaction between the light and the matter. The team, led by David Kim, a postdoc in the laboratory of Xiang Zhang, a professor of mechanical engineering at the University of California, Berkeley, found a new way to create the coupling effect. They turned the usual arrangement upside down by placing the resonators on top of each other, separated by a nanoscale gap. This allowed the coupling between the resonators to be much stronger than in the usual configuration. The new device could be used to enhance the efficiency of solar cells, in which the photovoltaic material absorbs only a fraction of the incident light. The material is generally chosen to absorb a particular wavelength of light, but it is ineffective at absorbing light at other wavelengths. If an optical antenna could be used to couple these "forbidden" wavelengths to the material, it would increase the overall efficiency of the device. The system could also be used to create an optical modulator, which could alter the amplitude, phase, or frequency of a light beam, potentially allowing a system to be used as a type of optical transistor. One application for this technology would be to speed up the data transmission in computer chips. Optical modulators have previously been made using a different type of superabsorption effect called electromagnetically induced transparency. However, these devices can only operate at very low temperatures. The new device works at room temperature, making it suitable for many applications.
text: A new type of optical device that absorbs light has been created by scientists at the University of California, Los Angeles, and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).

original_text: Silicon Valley security startup Verkada suffered a major security breach, with the hackers gaining access to over 150,000 of the company's cameras. Verkada serves companies like Tesla, Cloudflare, and Equinox, which are some of the biggest companies in Silicon Valley. The breach was discovered after the company's IT team noticed that its security cameras had been infected by malware, which caused the cameras to stop recording. The malware that caused the breach was a variant of the Zip Slip vulnerability, which allows an attacker to gain access to a system without any form of authentication. Verkada initially thought that the attack was the work of a random hacker, however, after further investigation, the company discovered that the malware was modified to specifically target Verkada's cameras, which suggests the attack was done by someone with inside information. "We're in the process of investigating and have engaged with a third-party security consultant to support our efforts," Verkada's co-founder and CEO Filip Kaliszan said in an interview. "We're evaluating our cloud infrastructure and are engaging with Amazon Web Services and other third-party providers to conduct comprehensive security audits." Verkada said that it believes that the attackers were able to gain access to its cameras after a former employee, who is now working for one of its competitors, stole Verkada's API key. The former employee apparently used the API key to gain access to the cameras, and then installed the malware. The malware, which has been named "Verkamontage," allows the attacker to gain full access to a camera and all of its features, including its video feed. This means that the hacker can remotely view footage from the camera and also disable it. Verkada said that they have been able to remove the malware from its cameras and that it is working to patch the vulnerability that allowed the attackers to gain access to the cameras.

original_text: GitHub Actions is an API for cause and effect on GitHub. Developers can orchestrate any workflow, based on any event, and GitHub will manage the execution and provide rich feedback. GitHub Actions is a new service that aims to make it easy to automate your development workflow, from project creation, through the build and deployment process, and finally through the release process. Currently, GitHub Actions is available in public beta.
text: GitHub Actions is an API for cause and effect on GitHub. Developers can orchestrate any workflow, based on any event, and GitHub will manage the execution and provide rich feedback. Currently, GitHub Actions is available in public beta.

original_text: Embeddinghub is a database built for machine learning embeddings. Embeddings are dense numerical representations of real-world objects and relationships. They are used to quantify how similar vectors are to each other and to represent natural language text, images, and other complex objects. Embeddings are also used as the basis of neural networks, such as deep learning models. In this way, embedding techniques have been used to solve many difficult machine learning problems, such as recognizing handwritten digits, classifying natural language text, and identifying faces. Embeddinghub is built on the TensorFlow Embedding Project. It currently has over 130 datasets, 108 of which are public, and it is growing daily. Embeddinghub allows users to explore embeddings with the TensorFlow Embedding Project, build custom embeddings, search and download public datasets, and share their own embeddings.
