original_text: SVGs have become popular due to their scalability, flexibility, and how lightweight they are. This article takes a look at SVG techniques such as SVG grids, fractional SVG stars, masks, and gradients, and provides some best practices when using these techniques. This article is the second of two articles that focus on techniques for using SVGs in modern web design. In the first part, we explored techniques for using SVGs for image replacement and as a scalable, lightweight alternative to raster images for backgrounds. In this part, we explore other useful techniques for using SVGs. One of the most common reasons for using SVGs is to represent shapes on the web. It might be a logo, icon, chart, or image of a product, or perhaps a simple shape. SVGs are perfect for representing these shapes because they can scale up and down without any loss of quality. There are many ways to do this, and we'll look at some examples in this article, including SVG grids, fractional SVG stars, masks, and gradients. Many tools exist for creating simple SVGs, like the ones mentioned above. Some of these tools even allow you to create SVGs directly within your HTML code. The free web app SVG-Edit, for example, lets you create SVGs and is ideal for experimenting with SVGs. As you can see, this simple method of generating an SVG is extremely flexible. You can use it to create many shapes, and even combine shapes with masks to create more interesting designs. The SVG file we've created has an svg element as its root element. It has three nested elements, each of which can be referred to by name via the prefix. The outermost element, a rect, represents the shape itself. The path element represents the mask that we added to the shape. The defs element contains the mask element that defines the shape of the mask. The mask is defined via an SVG path that tells the browser how to draw the shape. You can define the shape of the mask in many ways. The best way is to use a vector graphics editor like Adobe Illustrator, which can export shapes directly to SVG. If you're more technically minded, you can define the shape using the path element and the d attribute, which defines a series of points. This is covered in detail in the SVG specification. Whatever the case, once you've defined the shape, you can use the mask element to apply it as a mask to another SVG element. The mask element contains the shape that you want to use as a mask. It also defines how the mask should be applied, via the maskUnits attribute. In this example, we've used maskUnits"objectBoundingBox." This tells the browser to apply the mask to the entire object. The mask element has two child elements, rect and path. The rect element defines the dimensions of the object that the mask is applied to. The path element defines the shape of the mask. original_text: CSS linear gradients get washed out and muddy in the middle unless steps are taken to avoid the effect. This article teaches developers how to avoid the gray dead zone by using different color modes and calculating in-between colors. A gradient generator tool based on the information in the article is available.
text: CSS linear gradients get washed out and muddy in the middle unless steps are taken to avoid the effect. This article teaches developers how to avoid the gray dead zone by using different color modes and calculating in-between colors. A gradient generator tool based on the information in the article is available.

original_text: France is building a nuclear-powered aircraft carrier to replace its Charles de Gaulle carrier by 2038. According to French President Emmanuel Macron, the decision is part of France's climate strategy, and a nuclear-powered warship would output lower emissions compared to one powered by diesel fuel. An aircraft carrier would also help France project its global influence, as only a few countries in the world maintain the huge, costly vessels. The new aircraft carrier will weigh around 70,000 tons and measure 300 meters long. It will be designed to accommodate next-generation warplanes and serve until 2080. The estimated cost of the warship will be 7 billion euros.

The estimated cost of the warship will be 7 billion euros.

original_text: HTTPX is a next-generation HTTP client for Python which aims to provide more functionality than the requests module. In addition to the standard features of requests, HTTPX has sessions with advanced caching, cookies, and middleware. HTTPX is inspired by the Node.js HTTP client package 'axios', which has been popular with developers for its excellent API. HTTPX is an API-compatible drop-in replacement for requests, making it easy to migrate to HTTPX from requests. HTTPX is built on top of the requests module, so it has the same features as requests, such as supporting cookies, keep-alive, and streaming. HTTPX offers advanced features such as sessions, caching, and middleware. Sessions allow for easier state management of connections and cookies. Caching supports caching of HTTP response bodies, headers, and cookies. Middleware allows you to add additional functionality to an HTTP request, such as logging. HTTPX is intended to be an API-compatible drop-in replacement for requests. Simply import httpx instead of requests. For the majority of applications, this is all that is required. If you have a small number of requests that you would like to cache, you can use the cache decorator. For more information on the cache decorator, see the Cache Decorator Documentation. For a small number of requests that you would like to cache, you can use the cache decorator. For more information on the cache decorator, see the Cache Decorator documentation. HTTPX has support for the caching of all HTTP response parts, including response bodies, headers, and cookies. HTTPX supports cookies, session state, and automatic cookie management. HTTPX has built-in support for the following authentication methods: Basic, Digest, Token, and Bearer. HTTPX supports a middleware stack for adding functionality to HTTP requests. HTTPX has an extensive test suite which includes a full suite of benchmarks. HTTPX has a 100 test coverage, including type-checking coverage. HTTPX has first-class support for both Python 2.7 and 3.3. HTTPX is maintained by the requests community. HTTPX is currently in active development. The latest stable release is v0.6.0, which was released in June 2016. The next major version is HTTPX v0.8.0, which is currently in development. This version will introduce several new features, such as support for native pipelining, a middleware API, and support for automatic cookie management. HTTPX is a community-supported project, and we would like to thank the following companies and organizations for their generous support. If you would like to support HTTPX, please consider supporting the HTTPX project on Open Collective.

original_text: Apple is planning to build its own in-house technology and infrastructure for financial services. Financial services are a rapidly growing part of Apple's overall product strategy. Developing these services will take time and Apple doesn't want to wait for banks to build and provide the tools. The company is in talks with Goldman Sachs and Citigroup to offer a prepaid card that can be used for digital and physical payments. Apple has never offered its own banking services and it would be difficult to obtain a banking license in the US. However, in the UK and EU, Apple may be able to offer banking services through partnerships with large banks. In the United Kingdom, Apple may be able to apply for a restricted banking license to offer savings accounts and deposit services in partnership with a larger bank. In the EU, Apple could apply for an "e-money license" that allows it to offer limited banking services. There are some areas where the EU would require Apple to abide by the same rules as normal banks. However, Apple would be exempt from many of the rules and regulations that normal banks are required to follow.

original_text: Google will keep its 200,000 full-time and contract employees working remotely until at least July 2021. Sundar Pichai, CEO of Alphabet, made the announcement last week following a meeting with thousands of employees at its Mountain View headquarters. Pichai said he expects the policy to remain in place for a "long time" as the company focuses on its cloud-based business and its growing footprint overseas. "It's important that we make the right investments in infrastructure and ensure we have enough space for our people. There's a lot of work to be done," he said. In February, the company canceled its expansion plans in New York City after pushback from the community and local lawmakers. The company had planned to add 12,000 jobs to the city's growing tech scene. The move to remote work came about after the company's 2019 third-quarter earnings report. The company reported lower-than-expected profits due to the high cost of running its own data centers. Google is not the only company that has increased its remote workforce. Remote.co estimates that 63 of U.S. companies offer a remote work option. In addition, more than 70 of remote workers report being more productive when working remotely. "There's a lot of work to be done and we're going to work on that," Pichai said.
text: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, is extending its policy of allowing employees to work from home, according to the BBC's Laura Bicker.

original_text: OpenAI has released the full version of GPT-2, a text-generating AI system. When it was first announced, there were concerns that it could be misused to spread fake news, spam, and disinformation. OpenAI has since released smaller versions of GPT-2, but has seen no strong evidence of misuse. GPT-2 can generate coherent text from minimal prompts, for example, it can create an article from just a headline. Its limitations include having trouble with long-term coherence, for example, sticking to a single subject in a news article. There is an ongoing debate with AI researchers about the ethics of releasing cutting-edge AI tools that can enable malicious actors. OpenAI has created systems that can spot GPT-2's output with around 95 percent accuracy. A link to a web version of GPT-2 is available.

original_text: The Human Pangenome Project aims to gather, organize, and make accessible a representation of all genetic diversity found in people. The data could help reveal information about genetic risk for diseases, as well as the underlying biology of disease. On February 10, the research team launched a call for samples to be sequenced as part of the project. The launch coincided with a special issue of Genome Medicine, featuring articles that report the preliminary results of the first 350 genomes sequenced as part of the project. In the near future, when all genes are sequenced, the availability of this data will improve clinical decision making, and we will be able to tailor treatments to the genetic makeup of each patient. Dr. Stephen Scherer The study's investigators sequenced more than 350 people from around the world, including the Inuit people of Nunavut, northern Canada, and southern Africa, the Middle East, the Americas, and the Pacific Islands. The genomes were analyzed to determine the frequency of genetic variants among different populations. The data have revealed previously unknown DNA changes that may be associated with a risk of certain diseases. In the special issue, Scherer and his colleagues reported that the genetic code of Inuit people from Nunavut has a much higher number of differences in genetic code than in other populations. They also found that people from the Americas have a higher frequency of genetic variants that are linked to an increased risk of type 2 diabetes and obesity. Other findings in the special issue include: The first complete genome sequences from people of African ancestry. The researchers found that the African genomes had a higher number of small differences in their genetic code than the genomes from people of European ancestry. The African genomes also had higher numbers of genetic variants associated with a risk of Alzheimer's disease. The first genome sequence from an individual from Oceania. The researchers found that the individual carried a genetic variation that is associated with a higher risk of asthma and a lower risk of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. A genome sequence from an individual from the Middle East. The researchers identified a genetic variant associated with a lower risk of Parkinson's disease. The Human Pangenome Project is part of the Ontario Health Study, a long-term project by the Ontario Institute for Cancer Research (OICR). Scherer is the Director of OICR's Genome Informatics Program and Senior Core Scientist at SickKids' Research Institute. The Human Pangenome Project will be one of the largest genomic sequencing initiatives to date, and will generate data that will advance our knowledge of disease and help guide clinical practice. The project will also be a significant contribution to the study of human history and migration. Ashok Krishnamurty, President of OICR "We are excited by the groundbreaking discoveries and the implications of this research, and we are honoured to be hosting this project at the University of Toronto," says Krishnamurty. In addition to SickKids and the OICR, the project is being conducted in collaboration with the University of Toronto, McGill University, the Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care, and the University of California, Los Angeles. The Human Pangenome Project is supported by Genome Canada, the Ontario Institute for Cancer Research, the Ontario Ministry of Research and Innovation, and the Canada Foundation for Innovation.
text: Researchers at the University of California, Los Angeles, have sequenced the first 350 genomes as part of a global effort to map the human genetic code.

original_text: A Florida-based unmanned trucking company, Starsky Robotics, has set a record for the fastest that an unmanned truck has driven on a public road. It hit 55 MPH in a test on a closed section of Florida highway. To put this into perspective, the fastest that a truck driver can legally drive on the highway is 65 MPH. This means that the Starsky Robotics truck is just 10 MPH below the speed of its human counterpart. And if you're worried that this is just a PR stunt, don't be. Starsky Robotics was recently granted a license to test an unmanned truck on a closed portion of Florida highway. That's pretty significant, considering that no other autonomous trucking company has been granted a license for this yet. However, the company will have to wait a while before it can start to put its trucks on the road and deliver freight. Although the company has a license to test its unmanned trucks on the highway, the company does not have permission to operate them on public roads. This means that for the foreseeable future, a human driver will have to be on board with the truck during testing. This is actually a good thing, considering that many self-driving car companies, such as Waymo, don't require a human driver to be on board. The reason that these human drivers are required is to ensure that the trucks are safe to be on the road. Until they can prove that they are safe, they cannot be used to deliver freight on public roads.

original_text: A hacker claims to have stolen over 500GB of data from Microsoft's private GitHub repositories. The hacker had originally intended to sell the information but has now decided to give it away for free in order to put pressure on Microsoft. The hacker, going by the name of W0rm, has claimed to have stolen over 500GB of data from Microsoft's private GitHub repositories. The hacker had originally intended to sell the information but has now decided to give it away for free in order to put pressure on Microsoft. The hacker has released a torrent on his website that contains the stolen data. The data in the torrent is encrypted and the hacker has not released the key. According to the hacker, the key will be released if Microsoft fixes its security issues within 100 days of the posting. It is not currently known what types of data are included in the torrent. The hacker has claimed that the data is Microsoft's own intellectual property and that it would be harmful if it was leaked. W0rm first became known on the security scene back in 2011 when he claimed to have hacked the website of security firm Symantec. He then went on to claim that he had access to a variety of sources from the security firm, which he then leaked. The data included source code for Norton AntiVirus and corporate logins. W0rm claimed that he hacked Symantec's website using a vulnerability in the website's search engine. The hacker then returned to claim he had hacked the website of Citigroup and then released a large amount of data stolen from an Australian ISP. The hacker was later arrested and jailed in the UK for hacking the ISP. Although the hacker has a history of hacking, Microsoft has not commented on the incident. It is not clear why the hacker has decided to target Microsoft or whether the hacker has any connection with the company. It is also not clear what the hacker's motives are. The hacker claims he does not want to leak any of the data but it has not been revealed what he expects to gain from this threat. It is not clear why the hacker would have targeted Microsoft's GitHub repositories and not the company's main servers. Microsoft is not the first company to have a private GitHub account hacked. Earlier this year, the hacker who goes by the name of 0x90 took control of a number of GitHub accounts belonging to well-known companies. GitHub is a popular source code repository that is often used by companies.

original_text: President Donald Trump has signed an executive order that targets tech companies. Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act gives internet companies broad immunity from liability for the content their users post, which includes everything from Facebook and Google to Reddit and Twitter. The EO also requires the Federal Communications Commission to help combat robocalls, and to develop new ways to authenticate callers.

Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act gives internet companies broad immunity from liability for the content their users post, which includes everything from Facebook and Google to Reddit and Twitter. The EO also requires the Federal Communications Commission to help combat robocalls, and to develop new ways to authenticate callers.

original_text: Navigate on Autopilot is a new feature by Tesla that is moving it closer to its self-driving future. It offers step-by-step navigation overlayed on a map (like you would get from Google Maps or Waze) but the cool thing is that if you give it permission, it will execute the directions by itself. It can also be tuned for aggressiveness, with four modes: Disabled, Mild, Average, and Mad Max. This article is written by a reporter who got to try out Navigate on Autopilot for the first time, and he was very impressed, saying that he was "overcome with an ice-cold'this is the future' feeling."

original_text: Seattle Startup Zin Boats creates electric boats that can go a hundred miles or more and recharge using an ordinary wall plug. The boats require virtually no maintenance and can reach speeds of over 30 knots, with tests going up to 55 knots. Zin's boats were designed around the battery from scratch using high-performance fluid dynamics software and scale models to work out the shape of the hull. The 20-foot boats weigh around 1,750 pounds and are almost completely made out of carbon fiber. They cost around 250,000, with a more practical open-bow tender model currently being designed that will cost around 175,000. Images of the boats are available in the article.

original_text: Dwarf Fortress is a simulation game where players play in a deeply detailed randomly generated fantasy world. It was programmed by one developer, Tarn Adams, who has been working on it since 2002. It is a single player game which takes place on a 60 by 60 tile map (14400 tiles). Everything is represented on the map, from the tiniest rock to the largest mountain. The map is made of 3 dimensional tiles which can be mined and dug to create caves and tunnels. The game's main focus is the management of a dwarven fortress (as the name suggests) which the player creates. The dwarves are mostly nameless and faceless but have a distinct personality and career. Dwarf Fortress is a simulation game which allows players to make their own unique stories. The game has no plot, but it does have a setting. Players are free to do what they want in the game. There are two ways to play the game, either as a dwarf in a dwarven fortress, or as a human adventurer. Dwarf Fortress is free to play, but the developers encourage donations through their website. The game is currently in Alpha stage. Retrieved from "

original_text: Apple's HomePod mini smart speaker has a secret temperature and humidity sensor in its casing. It isn't currently usable by owners of the device yet, but Apple has previously included temperature and humidity sensors in its iPhones. The fact that the HomePod has a temperature and humidity sensor has been confirmed on Reddit by a user who says that they checked the software source code for the device. This sensor is not currently active on the HomePod, which is a bit like the current situation with the iPhone's sensors. Though they've been there since 2011, they haven't been activated for public use yet. The HomePod has a range of built-in sensors including an accelerometer, a microphone array, and a beam-forming tweeter. We know that the microphone array helps to enable the speaker's spatial awareness, and the accelerometer is used to detect when you're interacting with the speaker by tapping on it. The inclusion of a temperature and humidity sensor means that the HomePod could, in the future, be used to help you monitor the temperature and humidity of a room. As for why Apple included it in the first place, that remains unclear. It's possible that it's for internal testing, or it may be there to give Apple the option of activating it in a future software update. The HomePod is available now, and is Apple's first major smart speaker. In addition to Apple's own built-in features, it's also compatible with smart home platforms such as HomeKit and Apple's own Home app. This week on AI: HomePod reviews, rumors of iPhone SE 2, and more

original_text: A 3.1 billion dollar deal for Uber to purchase its biggest competitor in the Middle East, Careem, is expected to be made public on March 26. Uber is believed to have submitted an offer for Careem in a bid to become the largest ride-hailing service provider in the Middle East. The deal is expected to be announced on Tuesday, March 26, as per a source with knowledge of the matter, who spoke to Reuters. Uber's offer to acquire Careem for 1.4 billion dollars was made in late January, according to the source. Uber is expected to pay 1.4 billion dollars in cash and 1.7 billion in convertible notes, to acquire Careem. The notes will be converted into Uber shares after the IPO of the ride-hailing service provider. Earlier in March, Bloomberg reported that Uber had made an offer to acquire Careem for a deal valued at about 3.1 billion dollars. As per the Bloomberg report, Careem's investors had been resistant to the deal, with at least one of the investors pushing for a higher valuation. Careem is a ride-hailing service provider headquartered in Dubai, the United Arab Emirates. The company was established in 2012 by Magnus Olsson and Mudassir Sheikha. Careem operates in 90 cities across the Middle East, North Africa, Turkey, and Pakistan. The company has about 1 million drivers and 30 million registered users. Uber is a ride-hailing service provider based in San Francisco, the United States. The company was founded in 2009 by Travis Kalanick and Garrett Camp. Uber is currently present in about 600 cities across 65 countries. Careem and Uber are the leading ride-hailing service providers in the Middle East. The deal is being described by Reuters as a merger. A spokesperson for Uber declined to comment on the acquisition.

original_text: Cibo express has confirmed its first check-out free store at Newark Liberty airport. The store will use Amazon's Just Walk Out cashier-less technology. Just Walk Out uses the technology used in self-driving cars: computer vision, sensor fusion, and deep learning. Cibo Express plans to open five Just Walk Out Amazon Go stores at Newark Liberty International Airport by mid-2019, with the first one opening later this year. "We are thrilled to introduce Just Walk Out technology to our customers at Newark Airport. Our customers have high expectations when they visit New York airports, and we are always looking for new ways to delight them and make their airport experience more enjoyable. We are excited to be one of the first to offer this technology to our customers. We are always looking for innovative and modern solutions that enhance the customer experience," said Stephen Landau, President and CEO of Cibo Express.
text: The first Amazon Go store in the US will open later this year at one of the country's busiest airports. Cibo Express plans to open five Just Walk Out Amazon Go stores at Newark Liberty International Airport by mid-2019, with the first one opening later this month.

original_text: Scientists have grown plants in lunar soil using samples collected during the Apollo missions to the moon. The scientists grew thale cress, a small flowering plant that is attractive to researchers as it is well studied and its genetic code has been mapped. Almost all of the plants planted in the lunar soil sprouted. However, the plants showed signs of struggle and stress. Growing plants in the lunar soil could alter the moon's soil and make resources from the soil available in useful forms.

original_text: Researchers at Stanford University and the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory have discovered a way to transform a substance found in fossil fuels into diamonds with pressure and low heat. Diamond-like carbon can be used in high-tech applications such as solar cells and computer chips, and diamonds can be used for industrial applications, such as cutting tools, and for jewelry and investment. The new method is the first time researchers have been able to make diamonds and diamond-like carbon at room temperature. The diamond-producing substance is called benzene, which is commonly found in crude oil and natural gas. This method will allow more companies to produce diamonds in a cost-effective way. original_text: Java attempts to run trusted and untrusted code within the same virtual machine, with the only thing separating them being the permission system and visibility modifiers. A bug anywhere in the JVM implementation or in any of the code running in the JVM could lead to a security flaw that could allow an attacker to bypass the permission system. The problem is even worse when considering the use of scripting languages that use the JVM (such as Groovy and JRuby), because there is no way to ensure that all the code that gets executed was written in the language and not in Java. For example, you could execute a Groovy script containing a Java class that does something dangerous. Granted, this isn't a theoretical problem - Java's record for security is pretty good so far. Still, there's no such thing as perfect security, and having to worry about how to prevent one bug in the code that you can't see from taking down your whole program is a significant concern. Sun has been working on a solution to this problem for a while. It's called the Java Secure Execution (JSE) system. It's still in the early stages of development, but here's how it works: The current JVM is split into two pieces, the Java Virtual Machine (JVM) and the Java Secure Virtual Machine (JSVM). The JVM is what we know and love today, running all the Java bytecode in the program. The JVM is cut off from the operating system, and the only communication it has with it is via the JVM to JSVM bridge. The JSVM runs under a trusted operating system layer called the Java Security Kernel (JSK). The JSK is responsible for managing all the JSSE infrastructure, including the JSVM. The JSK manages the permissions of the JVM and all other JSSE components. A JSSE application has one JVM that runs the core application and, optionally, a second JVM that runs all the untrusted code. The untrusted code is run in the JSVM, and the JSVM acts as a bridge between the untrusted code and the operating system. Both JVMs are run under the JSK. The JSK can tell which parts of the JVM or JSVM have been compromised and shut them down, or at least limit their access to the operating system. When running a Java application, the JVM that runs the trusted code has a higher level of privilege than the JVM that runs the untrusted code, so it can always override any request made by the untrusted code. The JSK and JSVM are responsible for managing all aspects of security, including permissions, communication with the operating system, and resource allocation. The JSK is trusted to behave properly, and it can grant or deny access to resources. The JSVM is run under the JSK and doesn't have direct access to the operating system or other resources. The JSSE system gives the untrusted code as little access to the operating system as possible. The JSK monitors the JSVM for bugs or security flaws. If a problem is found, the JSK can shut down the JSVM or restrict its access to the operating system. The JSK is a trusted program and runs under the JSVM. The JSK runs under an operating system with a trusted, secure kernel that can verify the JSK's integrity and protect it from tampering. There is a chain of trust from the operating system through the JSK to the JVM. You might think that using the JSK adds yet another layer of complexity and makes it more difficult to find security bugs. The good news is that the JSK is written in Java, and it's more likely that a Java security bug will be found by the millions of Java developers worldwide than by a small number of kernel developers. The JSK isn't exactly a perfect solution, but it's the best one Sun has found so far. There's still a lot of work to be done before it's ready for use in the real world. It will probably be a few more years before the JSE is used in a production environment. For now, you'll have to make do with the current JVM and hope it doesn't have any security holes. text: Java attempts to run trusted and untrusted code within the same virtual machine, with the only thing separating them being the permission system and visibility modifiers. A bug anywhere in the JVM implementation or in any of the code running in the JVM could lead to a security flaw that could allow an attacker to bypass the permission system. The problem is even worse when considering the use of scripting languages that use the JVM (such as Groovy and JRuby), because there is no way to ensure that all the code that gets executed was written in the language and not in Java. For example, you could execute a Groovy script containing a Java class that does something dangerous. Granted, this isn't a theoretical problem - Java's record for security is pretty good so far. Still, there's no such thing as perfect security, and having to worry about how to prevent one bug in the code that you can't see from taking down your whole program is a significant concern. Sun has been working on a solution to this problem for a while. It's called the Java Secure Execution (JSE) system. It's still in the early stages of development, but here's how it works: The current JVM is split into two pieces, the Java Virtual Machine (JVM) and the Java Secure Virtual Machine (JSVM). original_text: Neuromorphic computing hardware is special hardware developed to model the behavior of biological neurons. A group of researchers from the US have developed a non-silicon version of the hardware that could be used to investigate how neurons communicate with each other. The researchers used a polymer material called P (VDF-TrFE-CFE) that has piezoelectric and ferroelectric properties. The combination of these two properties allows the material to exhibit some of the behavior that biological neurons are capable of, including synaptic plasticity, synaptic transmission, and short-term memory. In general, neurons communicate with each other through electrochemical signals. The signals are generated by voltage changes that occur when the neuron is stimulated by an external signal or by the activation of another neuron. The neuron generates an action potential that is transmitted to other neurons via synaptic connections. The synaptic connection consists of a small gap between the neuron and the target cell across which the electrical signal is transmitted. The synapse is similar to a capacitor in an electrical circuit. As the neuron sends the signal, the electric field generated at the synapse changes and can cause the polarization of the molecules within the synaptic junction. The molecules are then able to hold the polarization, thus forming a short-term memory of the signal. The polarized molecules can also be re-polarized by the reverse action potential of the next neuron. A neuron is a nerve cell that is the basic building block of the nervous system. Neurons are similar to other cells in the human body in that they have a cell membrane, a cytoplasm, and organelles. Neurons differ from other cells in that they generate and propagate electrochemical signals. A neuron consists of a cell body called the soma, and long fibers called dendrites and axons that project from the soma and extend to other neurons or muscles. A neuron uses the dendrites to receive signals from other neurons. The neuron integrates the signals it receives and generates an output signal that is sent to the axons. The axons send the signal to other neurons or muscles. The cell body contains the nucleus, which controls the cell metabolism and growth. The dendrites and axons have a sheath of myelin, which is a fatty substance that helps speed up the signal transmission along the axon. The sheath is interrupted at regular intervals to form gaps called Nodes of Ranvier. The sheath does not extend into the axon terminals. At the end of the axon, the signal is transmitted to another neuron through a synapse. A synapse is a gap between two neurons that is bridged by a neurotransmitter. The neurotransmitter is a chemical that is released by one neuron and received by another. The neurotransmitter transmits the electrical signal from the first neuron to the next one. A neuron is triggered by a signal that is generated by an external stimulus or by another neuron. The triggering signal is transmitted from the dendrites to the axon via the cell body and can travel as far as the axon terminal. At the axon terminal, the signal causes the opening of ion channels that allow ions to flow into and out of the neuron. The change in ion concentration generates an electric potential across the neuron membrane. The change in the electric potential travels down the axon as an action potential. The action potential is a change in the electric potential of the neuron that travels down the length of the axon. The action potential is generated when an ion channel opens and allows ions to flow into or out of the neuron. The ions flow into or out of the neuron through the ion channels in response to an external stimulus or a signal from another neuron. The action potential travels along the axon at about 120 meters per second and can travel as far as the axon terminal. When the action potential reaches the axon terminal, the action potential causes the release of neurotransmitters from vesicles. The neurotransmitters travel across the synapse and attach to receptors on the receiving cell. The neurotransmitter changes the electrical potential of the receiving cell and generates another action potential that travels along the axon of the receiving neuron. The release of neurotransmitters and the generation of the action potential that travels down the axon of the receiving neuron is referred to as synaptic transmission. Synaptic transmission can occur in one direction or in both directions. In

original_text: Wyze has confirmed that a server leak exposed the details of roughly 2.4 million smart device customers. An internal database was accidentally exposed online. Wyze was testing new methods to measure business metrics when a test database had its security protocols removed. The leak was discovered by a cyber-security consulting firm who only gave Wyze 14 minutes to fix the issue before going public with their findings. Leaked details include email addresses, device identifier data, and Alexa connection tokens. The security firm accused Wyze of exposing internal API tokens, sending data to Chinese servers, and collecting health information from users. Wyze has denied these accusations but noted that health data from 140 users was collected as part of a beta-test for a new smart scale product. As a response to the leak, Wyze has forced all users to log out from their devices and reset all API tokens.

As a response to the leak, Wyze has forced all users to log out from their devices and reset all API tokens.

original_text: Trevor Milton has stepped down from Nikola's board of directors. Milton will be replaced by Stephen Girsky, a former vice-chairman of GM. Nikola shares fell 22 percent in US pre-market trading. After GM announced that it would take an 11 percent stake in Nikola, short-selling firm Hindenburg Research released a report that accused Nikola of exaggerating its progress in technology. Nikola had recently released a video showing one of its trucks cruising down a hill, but Hindenburg claims that the video was staged. The Securities and Exchange Commission and the US Department of Justice are reportedly investigating the company.

original_text: Apple hit a 23 market share in China in Q4, 2021, thanks to the success of the iPhone 13. The new iPhone was a success due to its lower starting price and new features. The company is also the only one to benefit from the increased demand of the Chinese market for smartphones. Samsung and Huawei, which traditionally dominated the Chinese market, lost 4.5 and 3.8 percent respectively, due to Chinese customers' preference for Apple, according to Canalys. As a result, Apple's revenue in China increased by 18 percent to 40.3 billion yuan ( 5.6 billion) in Q4, a year-on-year increase of 18 percent. Apple's success in China was due to the low price of the iPhone 13. The handset was priced at 5499 yuan ( 781). The iPhone 13 and iPhone 13 Pro are now available in India. The iPhone 13 Pro starts at Rs 99,900, while the iPhone 13 starts at Rs 64,900. Apple's next iPhone model will be launched in September this year. Source: Apple, the second largest smartphone maker in China

original_text: This repository contains a PyTorch implementation of "Multi-Level Pixel-Aligned Implicit Function for High-Resolution 3D Human Digitization." The code can create high-resolution 3D models of humans from a single image. A trained neural network is used to estimate a dense implicit function and then an MCMC sampling step is used to optimize the function to a particular image. The code is based on the original C implementation. It was written by following the instructions in the paper. No code from the paper was used in this project. We recommend you install PyTorch using Conda. To run the examples, we recommend that you use the official PyTorch "lite" Docker image. To train the network, it is recommended to use a machine with at least a Titan X Pascal GPU. We have tested our code on NVIDIA GTX 1080 Ti, Titan X Pascal, Titan V, and Quadro P6000. Download the pretrained model and load it into PyTorch. We recommend using "lite" Docker image for your training machine. The code used to generate the results in the paper is included in the examples directory. See the examples for instructions on how to run the code and create high-resolution 3D models from images. If you use the code for a publication, please cite the paper. Use the button below to download a list of all files in the repository. Copyright 2019, University of California Regents. All rights reserved. To request permission to use materials from this website, please contact us.
text: The paper "Multi-Level Pixel-Aligned Implicit Function for High-Resolution 3D Human Digitization" was published in the journal Neural Computation in May 2016.

original_text: Metamaterials are materials made up of components that combine to create properties that are relatively independent of the properties of the original materials. Metasurfaces are flat structures that can manipulate the behavior of waves across a range of frequencies. Metasurfaces have been fabricated with various techniques and have been found to be useful in applications ranging from microwaves to optics, and from sensors to displays. Allen, et al., describe a fabrication process for metasurfaces made of 3D nanostructures. These metasurfaces can be used to manipulate the reflectance of waves in a broad frequency range. The metasurfaces can be used for free-space optical communication and applications that involve the manipulation of light. The metasurfaces were fabricated with a nanofabrication process that uses a combination of electron beam lithography and focused ion beam milling. The lithographic process was used to pattern the features of the metasurface into a thin layer of poly (methyl methacrylate). The milling process was used to remove material from the patterned features, leaving the 3D nanostructure. The metasurfaces were made up of nanowires. These metasurfaces were tested with broadband infrared and optical light, which were used to induce interactions with the metasurface. The nanowires were made of silicon and had a radius of 100 nm. The wires were spaced 200 nm apart. The wires were spaced at different distances to explore the differences in performance. The metasurfaces were fabricated with a variety of nanowire geometries. The metasurfaces were made with straight nanowires, curved nanowires, and nanowires with an S-shaped cross-section. The different geometries enabled the nanowires to be used in different ways. The metasurfaces were fabricated with a geometry that was designed to provide total reflectance. The total reflectance was achieved using the nanowires to create a structure that was similar to a Fabry-Perot resonator. The structure reflected infrared light at 10.5 m. original_text: JupyterLite is a JupyterLab distribution that runs entirely in the browser. It features a Python kernel backed by Pyodide, basic session and kernel management, code consoles, and more. It can be easily deployed without a dedicated application server. JupyterLite is still in active development.

original_text: An eight-year-old has discovered a way around her Apple Screen Time limits by using the iMessage App store. By accessing YouTube through the iMessage App store, the girl was able to keep watching YouTube well beyond her allotted app time. Children have always been finding ways around restrictions that parents place on them. Apple's parental controls aren't perfect, and iOS 13 was Apple's buggiest release in a long time. The company has since implemented new ways of developing and testing its software for the upcoming iOS 14 release.

original_text: Nvidia's Perlmutter supercomputer is the fastest in the world for AI workloads. Its first task will be to build a 3D map of the universe. The map will help scientists learn more about dark energy. With 6,000 Nvidia A100 Tensor Core GPUs on board, Perlmutter is capable of delivering almost four exaFLOPS of AI performance. Its performance will be bolstered further in phase two of its development. When it is completed, Perlmutter will be one of the top five supercomputers in the world.

Its performance will be bolstered further in phase two of its development. When it is completed, Perlmutter will be one of the top five supercomputers in the world.

original_text: Former Reddit CEO Yishan Wong is building a system to transform desert land into fertile ground to grow the trees we need to help stop climate change. Trees can recapture carbon, but first, they need water. Wong's company, Elementa, uses solar powered technology to desalinate and purify seawater and pump it to the roots of the trees, creating a healthy ecosystem where trees can grow. This technology could help create 100,000 acres of forest on 200,000 acres of land, turning the desert into an oasis of carbon-capturing forest. We are thrilled to announce our latest investment, Elementa, which will create forests in the desert and capture carbon from the atmosphere. Forests can also play a role in protecting biodiversity. Elementa's technology allows forests to grow in areas that are not currently suitable for trees. For example, in the Atacama desert in Chile, which is the driest desert in the world, Elementa is working with the National Forestry Corporation of Chile to create forests in the desert. These forests can help protect biodiversity because they will be home to thousands of native plants and animals, including the Atacama chinchilla, a critically endangered species of rodent that is the only mammal in the Atacama. original_text: NASA scientists discovered cyclopropenylidene in the atmosphere of Saturn's moon Titan. The simple, carbon-based molecule has never been seen in an atmosphere before. Titan has long been considered one of the most Earthlike places in our solar system, and has been theorized to be similar to our planet during its early days. The Cassini spacecraft, which orbits Saturn and has been sending back data since 2004, found that the simple hydrocarbon is a chemical precursor to life. "This molecule existed on the primordial Earth," said Martin Cordiner, an astrochemist at NASA Goddard Space Flight Center. "This tells us that complex organic chemistry can happen in alien environments, and that the building blocks of life are everywhere in the universe." Cyclopropenylidene is a simple molecule containing carbon and hydrogen atoms, and it's surprisingly common in the universe. It's produced in chemical reactions in laboratories on Earth, and exists in carbon-rich environments like meteorites and the atmosphere of Titan. The Cassini spacecraft, which was launched in 1997, has been studying Saturn's moons since 2004. Scientists first discovered methane in Titan's atmosphere during a flyby in 2004, and suspected that complex organic chemistry existed on the moon. But until now, the instruments on the spacecraft weren't sensitive enough to pick up the signal from cyclopropenylidene. The data showed that the molecule's abundance is comparable to methane's. The scientists believe that the molecule is formed when sunlight interacts with methane and other molecules in Titan's atmosphere. This causes the carbon-hydrogen bonds to break, allowing the molecule to form. "We are very confident in our findings because we were able to detect the molecule multiple times at various altitudes," said Conor Nixon, a planetary scientist at NASA Goddard and lead author of a paper on the discovery published in Science Advances. "We are now bringing together all of the data we collected in order to create a detailed picture of the chemistry of Titan's atmosphere." This discovery, along with others, suggests that Titan's atmosphere is a chemical factory, and has a complex network of reactions similar to Earth's. "We can't say for certain what forms of life may exist in Titan's methane-rich lakes and seas, but this new information will provide valuable insight into chemical processes occurring in the environment of this intriguing moon," said Scott Edgington, Cassini deputy project scientist at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. original_text: Clubhouse leaked a messaging feature called Backchannel to some users last week. Backchannel is a way for users to communicate over text instead of audio. The feature was not referenced in the app's release notes and it was clearly unfinished. Clubhouse was quick to remove it from the app. It released a statement acknowledging the feature, but warned that it was in testing and might not become a part of the app.

original_text: Facebook Gaming is launching on Android today. It is Facebook's attempt to take on the streaming community. The app will be available on iOS once it is approved on the app store. Facebook Gaming on iOS and Android is coming today In order to give people a taste of Facebook Gaming before the full-scale launch, the company has been testing the product in limited beta. Facebook Gaming is a community-based streaming app that will compete with the likes of Twitch and YouTube Gaming. Users can broadcast their gaming sessions, watch other gamers, and chat with other community members. You can also follow friends and favorite streamers to get notifications about their live streams. Facebook Gaming has been designed with a focus on game discovery. There is a Recommended For You section where you can find new games that you may like. The app will have a Watch Together feature that allows you to stream a game with a friend. You can play the game together and chat while playing. You will be able to create a Facebook Gaming profile from the Facebook Gaming app. The app itself is built upon the existing Facebook video technology. Facebook Gaming is also available on the desktop and in Messenger. In the coming weeks, Facebook will also roll out Facebook Gaming on Oculus. Facebook Gaming for iOS will be available in the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, UK, Ireland, Italy, and France. Android users can get the app in the US and UK. The app will be rolled out to more countries in the future.

original_text: Deep Nostalgia is an AI-powered service offered by online genealogy company MyHeritage that creates moving portraits from still photos. It uses pre-recorded driver videos of facial movements and applies them to old photos. Deep Nostalgia is an AI-powered service offered by online genealogy company MyHeritage that creates moving portraits from still photos. It uses pre-recorded driver videos of facial movements and applies them to old photos. The animations are so realistic that users are often moved to tears. The service, which was released earlier this year, has been used by more than 100,000 people, and more than 2 million videos have been produced using it. While there have been a number of AI-generated face manipulations, such as "DeepFake" videos in which a person's face is transposed onto another person's body, Deep Nostalgia is the first known use of the technology to animate still photos. The process takes less than two minutes to create a video of up to 30 seconds. MyHeritage founder and CEO Gilad Japhet told The Jerusalem Post that MyHeritage hopes to one day make the technology available to other companies, as well. MyHeritage is a family history and DNA-testing service based in Or Yehuda that also offers an online platform for building family trees, organizing family photos and sharing family history. The company has more than 96 million users worldwide and more than 45 million family trees on its site. MyHeritage was founded in 2003 by Japhet, who serves as the company's CEO. The Deep Nostalgia service is an extension of the company's MyHeritage Memory Box feature. When MyHeritage users upload photos of deceased family members, MyHeritage matches the photos with other photos from the same era to create a Memory Box. MyHeritage has a database of more than 300 million historical photos, including many from the World War II period. Japhet said that the idea for Deep Nostalgia was born after MyHeritage users began requesting moving pictures of their deceased loved ones. "There was a lot of demand for this. We thought, what if we could do something like this?" Japhet said. According to Japhet, the company has had several meetings with the Israeli government to discuss how the technology could be used to record the stories of Holocaust survivors and other elderly people for future generations. "We have many people who say, 'Oh my grandmother died years ago but I would love to hear her voice, Japhet said. There are currently two Holocaust survivors in Israel who are participating in a pilot program using the technology, he said. He added that the technology can be used to animate the faces of any photo, and in the future, MyHeritage hopes to offer a service that would allow users to animate their own faces and create videos of themselves. Japhet also said the company is developing a feature that would allow users to turn their smartphone photos into videos.

original_text: China's National Health Commission has confirmed the first case of human infection with H10N3, a strain of bird flu. The patient survived and there were no other cases. Widespread transmission of H10N3 among humans has not been documented, but it can cause severe disease. There are two types of bird flu: H1N1 and H1N2, both of which cause mild disease in humans. H5N1, H7N9, and H9N2 can cause severe disease and death in humans. The case of human infection with H10N3 was reported in the New England Journal of Medicine. The patient was a 67-year-old man from Suqian, Jiangsu Province, who had been exposed to infected poultry. He was hospitalized on March 2, 2019, with a fever and cough and was discharged on March 25 after recovery. The Jiangsu Provincial Center for Disease Control and Prevention reported the case to the national authorities. The National Health Commission set up a task force to determine whether the patient had been infected with H10N3. The task force concluded that the case was confirmed as H10N3 infection on the basis of the results of nucleic acid detection and virus isolation and by antigenic detection. H10N3 viruses can cause disease in humans. Infection is usually mild or moderate, but can be severe. Previously, the only confirmed human cases of infection with H10N3 were in Hong Kong in 2000, 2001, and 2003. The Hong Kong Department of Health reported that all three patients were infected with H10N3 viruses from poultry, and all three fully recovered. The H10N3 virus was isolated from poultry in China in 2000, 2003, 2011, 2013, and 2016, but no human infections were reported. The H10N3 virus is highly pathogenic for poultry. It has been found in poultry in China, South Korea, and Hong Kong. No human infection with H10N3 had been confirmed in Hong Kong since 2003, but the virus was isolated from live poultry in 2013 and 2016. In addition, the virus has been found in wild ducks in Hong Kong, the Department of Health said. This suggests that the H10N3 virus was circulating in poultry in China for some time before it caused infection in humans. The H10N3 virus in the patient in Jiangsu was found to have mutations in its gene for the hemagglutinin protein, which is the main target of antibodies produced by infected people and those vaccinated against influenza. The patient's H10N3 virus had mutations that reduced its ability to bind to human receptors in the respiratory tract. The virus's ability to bind to receptors in the respiratory tract may be an important factor in transmission of the virus. If the virus has reduced binding to receptors in the respiratory tract, it may be less able to cause disease in humans. Although the patient fully recovered, he developed a secondary bacterial infection that required antibiotic treatment. The H10N3 virus isolated from the patient in Jiangsu was found to be highly pathogenic for poultry. The virus was lethal to domestic ducks and chickens. The H10N3 virus also caused disease in ferrets, which are considered to be a model of human influenza infection. The virus was detected in the upper respiratory tract of infected ferrets and was transmitted to ferrets by direct contact. The authors of the New England Journal of Medicine report say that the infection of the man in Jiangsu with H10N3 "raises the possibility that this virus could cause additional cases of human infection in the future." "To date, widespread transmission of H10N3 among humans has not been documented, and no severe disease or death has been reported in humans. Influenza viruses, including H10N3, can cause severe disease and death in humans. This is the first documented case of human infection with H10N3, a virus that has circulated among poultry for many years. "The risk for human infection with this virus is likely low

original_text: While CRISPR technology has the potential to help many people, it also has the potential to be used as a dangerous weapon. The technology works by editing genes within living things, which is a relatively new idea. This technology can be used to potentially cure diseases, and even cure cancer, but this also means that this technology can potentially be used for harmful purposes. In the USA, CRISPR technology is regulated by the FDA, but only for certain applications. The FDA regulates gene editing in animals and human cells for treatment purposes. However, genome editing in humans for reproductive purposes is not regulated by the FDA. This means that the application of CRISPR in humans is completely unregulated, and this is a potential problem. If CRISPR technology was used in humans, we would not be able to predict what would happen to that person. If the technology was used to cure a genetic disease, then the person could end up with a different genetic disease. If the technology was used to help a person's immune system, then the immune system could end up attacking the person's body. In the event that CRISPR technology was used to enhance people, then their offspring could potentially have even more enhancements. The possibilities for negative outcomes from CRISPR technology are endless. In summary, CRISPR technology is a relatively new scientific concept, and there are a lot of applications for the technology. However, the technology also has the potential to be used for harmful purposes. This is something that we as humans need to be aware of, and we need to make sure that the technology is used responsibly. We need to make sure that we do not use the technology to harm people, but rather use it to help people.

original_text: Fortescue Future Industries (FFI), an Australian mining company, has announced a project to create an electric infinity train that will be able to move loads of iron ore without ever needing to be charged. The battery-electric locomotive will regenerate electricity on downhill loaded sections, removing the need for recharging infrastructure. The company has mining sites where there is enough downhill slope for the idea to work. FFI's other green-tech projects include an ammonia-powered ship, hydrogen fuel cell mining trucks, and ammonia-fueled trains.

original_text: The basking shark is an endangered species that feeds on zooplankton, tiny creatures found near the surface of the ocean. It was once common off the coast of western Europe. A recent study has found that basking sharks like to travel to areas where there are high densities of zooplankton to feed. This causes hundreds of basking sharks to converge in inshore surface waters on the Scottish west coast, Ireland, and the Isle of Man. More than 80,000 basking sharks were slaughtered for their oily livers in the second half of the 20th century. The study reveals previously unknown behaviors about the sharks to conservationists, allowing them to more effectively protect the species.
text: The basking shark is an endangered species that feeds on zooplankton, tiny creatures found near the surface of the ocean. It was once common off the coast of western Europe. A recent study has found that basking sharks like to travel to areas where there are high densities of zooplankton to feed. This causes hundreds of basking sharks to converge in inshore surface waters on the Scottish west coast, Ireland, and the Isle of Man. More than 80,000 basking sharks were slaughtered for their oily livers in the second half of the 20th century. The study reveals previously unknown behaviors about the sharks to conservationists, allowing them to more effectively protect the species.

original_text: DuckDuckGo is working on a desktop browser that will help users avoid being tracked. The browser will have robust privacy protection turned on by default and function in the same manner as the DuckDuckGo search engine. More and more people are beginning to question the data privacy practices of tech giants, with many realizing that they are unknowingly handing over more personal information than they would like to. Companies such as Facebook and Google have made a lot of money from user data and they have come under fire for the way in which they make money. These businesses are aware that users have become concerned about how their data is used, and they have started providing users with more control over their data. However, users still need to opt-in to most of the privacy settings and most have not been turned on by default. Many people simply don't take the time to change their privacy settings, but DuckDuckGo is trying to change that. The company has made its name from building a search engine that doesn't track users and that doesn't save user data. The company has now decided to tackle the issue of browser tracking by building a new browser that will have DuckDuckGo's privacy protection features built in. The browser will run on Chromium's open-source code, which is the same code that Google Chrome is based on. Many browser extensions exist that can protect users from trackers, but many of these are not turned on by default, which means that users have to go out of their way to download and install them. DuckDuckGo will take a different approach by integrating privacy features directly into the browser itself. This means that users won't have to install any extensions or download anything to protect their privacy. In a recent blog post, DuckDuckGo stated that privacy is not only a fundamental right, it's also a critical foundation for a functioning society. The company believes that privacy is not a feature to turn on and off but a basic requirement that should be at the forefront of everything. DuckDuckGo is currently asking for feedback on the new browser. People can sign up to get early access to the browser, and DuckDuckGo is also looking for people to test it. The company has revealed that it is working on a number of new features for the browser, including an offline mode that will mean that websites that don't normally load offline will be able to load when there is no internet connection. Many companies such as Apple have been looking at ways to tackle the issue of data privacy, and DuckDuckGo is taking a similar approach. The company is looking to help users understand what data is being collected and why. DuckDuckGo aims to empower users with the tools they need to control what information is collected about them. The company will release more details about the browser in the future, but for now, it's asking users for feedback and advice.

original_text: Intel will invest at least 20 billion on a new chip manufacturing site in New Albany, Ohio. The location will host two chip factories and employ at least 3,000 people. Intel expects the site to become the largest silicon manufacturing location on the planet, with plans to expand it to eight fabs. Ohio was chosen for the site as it was a better regulatory fit and building it would not displace any current residents. The site will become operational in 2025.

The technology is expected to make home building cheaper, since it will eliminate the need for construction workers and expensive machinery. original_text: The Senate's new infrastructure bill may shape the future of cryptocurrency in the US. The bill promises public spending on major projects and it proposes taxes on crypto brokers to fund the projects. There are two competing amendments, one that exempts miners, hardware manufacturers, and developers, and another that only exempts proof-of-work cryptocurrencies. The definition of brokers in the original bill was so broad that anyone involved in cryptocurrency services would have to report to the IRS information on their customers, which would be impossible for most of the industry. The vote on the rival amendments is expected to take place on Saturday.

original_text: RediSQL is a fast, in-memory, SQL engine. Based on Redis, it is easy to use, works with standard SQL, and can reach speeds of up to 130,000 inserts per second. Due to its speed and storage mode, it is effective in creating lightweight, temporary databases for testing. The code is stable, so RediSQL can be used as a main database with on-disk storage if desired. RediSQL has complete JSON support and is fully text-searchable. There is full documentation available and guides on using RediSQL on Python, Node.js, and Golang.

original_text: A Mexican startup called Biomitech has developed an artificial tree that it claims is capable of processing the same amount of air pollution as 368 living trees. Unlike trees, Biourban doesn't require many years to grow. The 14-foot metal tree uses microalgae that pulls carbon dioxide and other contaminants from the air, releasing pure oxygen as a byproduct. According to the World Health Organization, an estimated 7 million people die from exposure to air pollution each year. Each artificial tree costs around 50,000 to construct, which might prevent the technology from spreading to areas where it is needed most. Another project from a German firm, Green City Solutions, uses vertically installed squares of moss cultures to achieve similar results.

original_text: Apple announced updates to iOS, iPadOS, MacOS, TV OS, and WatchOS in the opening keynote for WWDC2020. Public betas will start next month. iOS 14 will introduce new capabilities for Siri, Messages, Home, and Maps, as well as the ability to view PIP video. iPadOS 14 introduces a sidebar to several of Apple's apps, compact notifications, an OS-wide search, and a new Scribble App. macOS Big Sur is the next big update to macOS which will feature a complete redesign, a tool to port iOS apps to macOS, faster loading times for Safari, and more security features. WatchOS 7 will make customizing watch faces easier, and grant users the ability to share faces as well. It adds sleep tracking, the ability to track handwashing, as well as dance routines. A new Metal-optimized graphics processor and other custom acceleration silicon will ship in systems by the end of 2020 and be rolled out to the rest of the Mac line over the next two years.

WatchOS 7 will make customizing watch faces easier, and grant users the ability to share faces as well. It adds sleep tracking, the ability to track handwashing, as well as dance routines. original_text: Gene Levoff, the previous senior director of law and corporate security at Apple until September last year, has been charged with securities fraud and is set to appear in court on Thursday for "insider trading." According to the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), Levoff bought stocks in Apple's suppliers ahead of earnings announcements that would cause Apple's stock price to rise, making Levoff a profit. Levoff had been doing this from 2011 to 2016, having earned US225,350 from insider trading, according to the SEC. Levoff was fired by Apple after an internal investigation by Apple found that he had made trades using information about unreleased products. Levoff is said to have bought stock in Apple's suppliers based on what he learnt about products he had worked on. The SEC says Levoff bought stock in companies such as Skyworks Solutions, Dialog Semiconductor, and Micron Technology. Apple has now come out in support of the SEC's allegations, saying in a statement to Bloomberg that they "found the conduct described to be completely unacceptable." The US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York has also brought criminal charges against Levoff, with the US Attorney's Office accusing Levoff of earning US440,000 from insider trading. Levoff will appear in court on Thursday to face the charges, where he is expected to plead guilty. We've reached out to Apple for comment and will update the article should they respond. Apple will be reporting its first quarter earnings for FY19 on Thursday evening.

Microsoft founder Bill Gates has stepped down from his position on the board of Berkshire Hathaway. Gates stated that he decided to step down in order to dedicate more time to his role at the Bill Melinda Gates Foundation. Gates acquired a stake in Berkshire Hathaway in 2016 and purchased additional shares in the holding company last year. He was elected to Berkshire Hathaway's board of directors in 2018. "I love Warren Buffett, and I love what he and Charlie Munger have done. It's been an honor to be a small part of it. It's been a privilege for me to be a shareholder, and I'm not going to be selling my shares," said Gates. Gates has also stepped down from his position on Microsoft's board after serving as a board member for 35 years. Gates co-founded Microsoft and served as the company's CEO until 2000. He later served as the company's chairman. "Being a part of the board for 35 years has been a fantastic experience. I'm not stepping down because we are entering some kind of period of uncertainty. Quite the contrary, I think the 43-year run we are on is simply spectacular," said Gates. "I will continue to be in touch with Microsoft as I have been throughout this process, and I am sure we will work together on some projects in the future." Gates says that he will spend more time at the Bill Melinda Gates Foundation. He states that he is excited to focus on the work of the foundation and its partners around the world. "It's been a fantastic journey and we're not nearly done," said Gates. Gates is one of the founders of the Bill Melinda Gates Foundation. The foundation focuses on issues such as poverty, health, education and clean energy.

original_text: Bitcoin mining uses a huge amount of electricity. A mining setup requires a building, hundreds of high-speed computer servers, a heavy-duty cooling system, and a location that can handle a lot of electricity. Back in 2013, many bitcoin miners were attracted to the area around the Columbia River due to the cheap power from the five hydroelectric dams along the river. Many properties in the area were converted to cryptocurrency mines. Other regions in the world with cheap electricity have also seen a rise in mining hubs. Bitcoin's popularity has now increased to the point where it is no longer feasible for smaller operators to continue mining.

original_text: Python 3.9 was released on October 5 and as with every new version of Python, it includes new, improved, and deprecated features. A link to the complete list of changes can be found at the end of this article. Let's have a look at the new features of Python 3.9. Python has built-in modules that can be used to perform scientific calculations such as statistics, calculus, interpolation, etc. The new version of Python brings several improvements to the functionality of the NumPy, Matplotlib, and Pandas modules. NumPy is the standard scientific library in Python that includes a multidimensional array object and provides the tools to create vectors, matrices, and tensors, as well as perform calculations on those objects. The 3.9 release includes significant improvements to the speed and functionality of this module. Performance is improved by 10-30 for indexing, slicing, and item assignment. New functionality has been added to the ufunc module, a group of common mathematical functions. It now supports multi-dimensional arrays. The module now includes a more robust implementation of the underlying data structure, the Array Object. This is also the reason for the improved performance of the module. The module includes additional functionality that makes it easier to handle and visualize data with many dimensions. Pandas is a data analysis library that provides a high-performance data structure called DataFrame. It has an API that allows users to perform operations such as loading data from files, performing mathematical calculations, and creating charts. The DataFrame module now includes a more efficient method of loading data from files in the form of Parquet files. Parquet is a columnar data format developed by Apache that provides efficient storage and querying of large datasets. The new functionality makes loading data from Parquet files much faster than in previous versions of Python. Improvements have also been made to the underlying C data structure for the DataFrame module, which results in an overall improvement to the functionality of the module. Matplotlib is the plotting library in Python that is used to create charts and graphs. The 3.9 release includes several improvements to the functionality of the library. Previously, the memory requirements for drawing charts with a large number of data points would be excessive, but now it is possible to display them without exceeding the memory limits of the computer. The module now includes the ability to support the color spectrum, which is useful when displaying charts with many colors. As mentioned, the built-in modules for scientific calculations now include many improvements, but they are not the only modules that have seen improvements. Many other modules such as random, multiprocessing, and datetime have also been improved. The random module, which provides functionality for generating random numbers, now has the ability to use a new random number generator that provides better performance. The multiprocessing module now has the ability to use the fork method of creating processes on Windows. Previously, it could only use the spawn method, which is not as efficient. The datetime module, which provides functionality for working with date and time values, now has the ability to convert date and time values to and from the ISO 8601 format, which is an internationally recognized format for representing date and time values. Python 3.9 is a significant update to the language, and the performance of the NumPy, Matplotlib, and Pandas modules have been significantly improved. Many other built-in modules have also been improved. This is an important release for the Python community, and hopefully, it will be an improvement for your projects as well. The complete list of new features can be found at the Python 3.9 New Features documentation.

The multiprocessing module now has the ability to use the fork method of creating processes on Windows. Previously, it could only use the spawn method, which is not as efficient. The datetime module, which provides functionality for working with date and time values, now has the ability to convert date and time values to and from the ISO 8601 format, which is an internationally recognized format for representing date and time values. Python 3.9 is a significant update to the language, and the performance of the NumPy, Matplotlib, and Pandas modules have been significantly improved. Many other built-in modules have also been improved. This is an important release for the Python community, and hopefully, it will be an improvement for your projects as well. The complete list of new features can be found at the Python 3.9 New Features documentation.

original_text: Ten eggs were harvested from the last two remaining northern white rhinoceroses, potentially saving the species from extinction. Neither of the white rhinos can carry a baby to term, so scientists from Kenya and the United States implanted the eggs in southern white rhinoceroses. It's not the first time a northern white rhino egg has been fertilized in vitro, but it's the first time an embryo survived. The team injected the sperm of a northern white rhino male into the eggs. Although the male died in 2014, scientists were able to salvage some of his sperm. "Throughout their history, rhinos have recovered from the brink of extinction, so we hope that we can use this development to help the northern white rhino recover too," said Katsuhiko Hayashi, head of the BioResource Center at the University of Kyoto. "This is the first step in a long process," said Richard Vigne, CEO of the Ol Pejeta Conservancy. "We are encouraged by this news, as it proves that there is still hope for the northern white rhinos." Mother and son among 7 killed in crash at Kennedy airport, NY

original_text: Russia plans to temporarily disconnect the entire country from the internet in an exercise designed to test the country's internet infrastructure in case of a cyber-war. The test is expected to happen before April 1. An unexpected disruption to the internet could cost the country billions, even if the disruption is only brief. Russia plans to route all of its internet traffic within the country by 2020, and the testing is part of a plan to create a web filtering system similar to the one in China.

original_text: There is a gene that codes for a protein called cytochrome P450, which exists in many mammals' livers, helping them clean up toxins. Scientists spliced this gene from a rabbit's liver into a common houseplant, hoping to create an inexpensive way to clean up contaminated soils. Agriculture professor Shou-Tung Fan, along with a team of students, genetically engineered the houseplant Arabidopsis to produce a protein that can break down pollutants. The goal is to engineer plants that can live in contaminated soil and clean it up. Arabidopsis is a small flowering plant related to broccoli and cabbage. The team inserted the gene into Arabidopsis and grew the plants in a hydroponic solution containing atrazine, a common agricultural herbicide. Arabidopsis is a small flowering plant related to broccoli and cabbage. The team inserted the gene into Arabidopsis and grew the plants in a hydroponic solution containing atrazine, a common agricultural herbicide.The team found that the engineered Arabidopsis plants broke down the atrazine, and also the toxic byproduct produced when the atrazine was broken down. Arabidopsis is a small flowering plant related to broccoli and cabbage. The team inserted the gene into Arabidopsis and grew the plants in a hydroponic solution containing atrazine, a common agricultural herbicide.The team found that the engineered Arabidopsis plants broke down the atrazine, and also the toxic byproduct produced when the atrazine was broken down.The next step, says Fan, is to work with a better atrazine-degrading gene. "We want a gene that is better at cleaning up atrazine, and we want to introduce this gene into another species that can grow in the field," he said.
